PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service;
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia;
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 472 citizens), Cook (from 29 citizens), Cooney (from 10 citizens), Giles (from 80 citizens), Maguire (from 207 citizens) and Vanstone (from 150 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Mordechai Vanunu: Release from Prison
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Our deepest concern at the plight of Mordechai Vanunu, who revealed details of the nuclear weapons arsenal of Israel;
Our belief that Vanunu's actions were a service to humanity-including to the people of Israel-and were in fulfilment of his duty under international law;

Our belief that the unlawful abduction of Vanunu from Rome, his imprisonment since then, his prison conditions, and his conviction on charges of espionage and treason are denials of his fundamental human rights.

Resolve to ask the Australian Government to appeal to the Government of Israel to release Mordechai Vanunu immediately and without conditions.

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that.

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains a satellite communication dish, that sends to the United States the information, gathered by the ``joint high frequency stations'' in Australia and New Zealand, indicating the position of the Soviet naval ships and submarines.
This information from Watsonia is combined with data from satellites and underwater sensors to calculate the location of the Soviet vessels with great accuracy.

2. This would make it possible for the US nuclear naval ships and submarines to destroy all nuclear Soviet naval ships and submarines, while the US nuclear submarines, naval ships and bombers launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
3. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
4. The ``joint U.S.-Australian'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the ``Joint Australian-U.S.'' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation

1. That we are totally opposed to the introduction of a compulsory national identification system under the control of the Federal Government.

2. That we reject the identity card proposal because it will involve massive expenditure of taxpayers funds while being ineffective in combating the problems of tax evasion, illegal immigration and abuse of the social security system.

PETITION.TITLE: War Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of the undersigned members of the War Veterans' community and concerned citizens respectfully showeth:

That there has been continuous, substantial and damaging erosion of war veterans' benefits and services since May of 1985 in the areas of: the deletion of the dependants' pension; the removal from the Department of Veterans Affairs repatriation schedule pharmaceuticals of war widows, their dependants and service pensioners; a reduction in dental benefits; the deletion of the ten percent disability pension assessment previously allowed when glasses were prescribed; the restriction on the issue of glasses and other associated losses in benefits to partially blind veterans; the lack of protection in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 for intermediate or special rate pension rates disability pensions; the loss of benefits in respect of reimbursement of substantial costs incurred in obtaining medical opinion in support of a claim or an application; the means testing of the war veterans' children education scheme; the deletion of the intellectually handicapped dependants' allowance; the freezing of the social security portion of pensions paid to war widows; the restriction of travelling and mileage allowances; the termination of the defence re-establishment agricultural and loans schemes; the loss of the automatic right of admission to private hospitals without prior approval of a DMO; the imposition of a nursing home patient contribution rate for war veterans who are resident in nursing homes or who are receiving psychiatric treatment for war related disabilities; the abolition of the defence service home loan scheme; reductions in the of skin care, podiatry and physiotherapy treatments; and abuses in the use of information supplied by war veterans in responses to lifestyle questionnaires;

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Withdrawal of Notice of Motion for Disallowance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement and to withdraw Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for today relating to the disallowance of the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday, 22 February, I gave notice of a motion to disallow the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987. I did so because of the unacceptable changes which this Ordinance would have produced in the Schools Authority of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). When the ACT. Schools Authority was first constituted in 1974, it was widely praised as introducing a new era in education, and a new pattern of democratic involvement in education by parents and educators, as well as ministerial nominees. This was not just another government department responsible to a Minister, but a self-standing and representative Authority, with an independent chair. This system came into being in response to the needs of the community expressed during years of intense community discussion and debate. It was in marked contrast to the big, centralised, bureaucratic and authoritarian education systems of the other States.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the main features of the ACT system were: an independent statutory authority, rather than a government department responsible to a Minister; community and teacher participation-mechanisms which guaranteed parent and teacher representation in the governing body and in local school councils; and a decentralised and flexible school system. The decision by the Government last year to abolish the Schools Authority Council and to vest authority in a Chief Education Officer undermined everything which had made the ACT system unique and successful. Parent participation was reduced to a meaningless level. The powers of the Council were all placed in the hands of one man, a bureaucrat who, however virtuous, is not accountable to the community. The ACT community did not accept this decision. Representative groups from all over the ACT made their views clear to me and, I believe, to other senators. It was as a result of this overwhelming public response that the Australian Democrats moved to disallow the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. This appears to be not a notice of motion but far more in the nature of a speech on the subject. It is a long des- cription--
—I understand that Senator Jenkins sought leave to make a short statement before she withdrew a notice of motion. This is an explanation. I must say that it is not necessarily brief, however.

—If I may speak to the point of order: the agreement between the Democrats Whip and me was that, if leave were granted to make a short statement, it would take about two minutes and that we would make a statement of about two minutes as well.
—Mr President, I have about half a minute left.
—I suggest that you continue.

—It was as a result of this overwhelming public response that the Australian Democrats moved to disallow the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance. A month later, at the last minute, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) produced a Press release in which he suggested a number of compromises. These were clearly inadequate, but they indicated that the Minister was at least amenable to argument. In response to a further letter, in which I spelled out the minimum requirements put to me by community representatives, the Minister announced a further series of modifications to his original statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that these statements were made in good faith, and that the ACT community will be satisfied with them. For this I commend the Minister, and I look forward to a similar clear-sightedness on his part concerning the ordinances dealing with technical and further education and the Canberra Institute of the Arts. I withdraw the notice of motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The facts have been outlined. The Liberal Party would not support a situation in which the Authority was changed so that only one person ran the Authority, with no community input at all. We put it to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) that at the very least there should be an advisory council set up with some status and function in this. It is not what most people interested in the school community really wanted, which was the larger authority that previously existed. This is a compromise which the Minister has agreed to. It was confirmed again last night at a Senate Estimates committee hearing that the legislation would be in place in May and this authority established in relation to the ACT Schools Authority and the Institute of Technical and Further Education. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter written by the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, to Senator Vanstone in which he indicates that he will make these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator A Vanstone
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Vanstone

In view of the representations I have received, should the motion to disallow the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987 be defeated, I have decided to make changes in the advisory arrangements for the A.C.T. Schools Authority and A.C.T. Institute of Technical and Further Education.

In the case of the Schools Authority, the Ordinance will be amended to introduce a statutory advisory committee with the features set out in this letter in place of the committee established by the Schools Authority (Amendment) Ordinance 1987.

This advisory committee will have 7 members: an independent chairperson appointed by the Minister, 2 school board chairpersons, 1 Ministerial member and 1 representative each from the Parents and Citizens Association, the A.C.T. Teachers Federation and the Pre-Schools Association.

The functions of the committee will be as set out in the attachment to this letter, and will be specified in the Ordinance. The committee will report to the Minister and will have not less than 8 meetings a year. The Chief Education Officer will be required to take account of the committee's advice in the performance of the Authority's functions.
Similar arrangements will be made for the A.C.T. Institute of Technical and Further Education where the Ordinance will be amended to establish a statutory advisory committee with 7 members.

The independent chairperson of the committee will be appointed by the Minister and the committee will have 3 Ministerial nominees and 1 representative each of the Teachers Federation, students and industry.

Appropriate functions of the committee will be based on those developed for the Schools Advisory Committee and will be specified in the Ordinance. The other features as listed above for schools will also apply in the case of the TAFE advisory committee.

These changes will require amending ordinances which will be made and tabled in Parliament in the near future. Meanwhile interim arrangements consistent with the proposals outlined in this letter will be established.
Yours sincerely
GARY PUNCH

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942 in relation to television licences, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Powell) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I introduce this Bill which will have the effect of amending the Broadcasting Act 1942 to reduce the limit on television ownership to 43 per cent of the total national audience from the present figure of 60 per cent. This is an issue of utmost importance for Australia, with the almost daily increasing concentration of all sections of the media.

We have one overwhelmingly dominant print media owner, Rupert Murdoch, whose metropolitan papers account for 62 per cent of the total sales. That one person has been allowed to build up such an empire is a tragedy for this country and a reflection on this Government's lack of adequate media regulation.

That radio ownership laws are more stringent is in no small part the result of pressure by the Australian Democrats in that area. If not for the Democrats, the national limit in radio of 16 stations would be much higher and there would be no State limit.

However, nowhere is the concentration of the media a more serious problem than in television ownership. There are now three people dominating the television industry. This is the result of the historic backroom deal between Labor and the Nationals which was done just prior to the last Federal election when the National Party was running around loose, having broken out of coalition.

So the big three were given a free go to buy up 60 per cent of the television media in this country, effectively forcing several medium level players out of the game. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal had already awarded the third Perth television licence to Kerry Stokes after an exhaustive inquiry, costing the taxpayer millions of dollars. But no sooner had the ink dried, and before the station went to air, than it was sold at massive profit to Frank Lowy's Westfield, who was now allowed to push his audience share to 60 per cent. So the Labor and Nationals deal, which was blatantly designed to improve their media coverage during the election, saw another media proprietor bow out. The move has so far seen the number of metropolitan television owners drop from nine to five.

But that does not seem to be enough, either for the Government or the largest media owners. Despite the fact that the present limit is 60 per cent, at least one owner has ignored this by moving his market share beyond this.

Rather than taking steps to ensure compliance, the Government is prepared to change the laws to accommodate its media mates. At a time when the Labor Party claims it has heard the electoral message that the Australian people want the Government to look after their interests rather than those of big business mates, this is quite an amazing decision. The Government has failed its first test dismally.
Clearly, however, Government ranks are split on the issue and it remains to be seen whether the Cabinet line will prevail.

If it is hard to predict which way the Labor Party will jump, then it is even more difficult to work out where the Opposition stands. Last time the Liberals held a definite position was last year when they favoured a 43 per cent limit.

Senator Chris Puplick, in his dissenting report from the Senate Select Committee on Television Equalisation, said: `for all these reasons I reject the premise of this Bill in relation to the 75 per cent audience reach rule and would limit any such level of domination to no more than 43 per cent as originally proposed by Minister Duffy'. And Ian Macphee has publicly committed himself to supporting a reduction in the audience reach limit.

The question now is whether these reasonable views will prevail or whether we will once again see an unholy alliance of the ALP and the Liberal and National parties as we so often do-acting against the interests of the ordinary people, succumbing to pressure to support the vested interests of big business.

What exactly will a move to a 43 per cent limit achieve? Firstly, it will reduce the enormous social and political power of the present big three: Bond, Skase and Westfield. It is quite wrong to deliver the political future of this country into their hands and in these days of electronic presidential-style elections that is what the reality is.
As the Treasurer himself said only last week:
The importance of television in formulating and developing public opinion is unquestioned . . . . . . .

Secondly, it will encourage new players into television ownership. The greatest protection we have is in the widest possible ownership of our media. The Government stated this as its aim, and this legislation will bring that about.

Thirdly, it will prevent regional television being engulfed. If the limit is raised to 75 per cent it will allow those who presently dominate the metropolitan scene to carry on and buy up major regional media holdings as well.

Fourthly, it will redress the imbalance in negotiations between the major networks and regional groups aligned with the network. Effectively they are told what will be produced, what they will buy and even when they will show it. By lowering the limit to 43 per cent this wide disparity in power will be reduced. Moving to 43 per cent will mean that Sydney and Melbourne will not be the sole considerations in production and programming decisions.
It will mean at least six commercial operators with large enough networks to finance significant production, and greater localism of program content is more likely.

This Bill will involve divestment by those currently exceeding the 43 per cent level. Obviously if three are already above that level divestment is necessary. A three-year period is allowed so that the present owners will have adequate time to find buyers.

The United States Federal Communications Commission has used divestment orders in media ownership questions. Both Mr Keating and Mr Mick Young have in the past advocated divestment in this context. Similarly, Senator Chris Puplick has stated: `I believe that a policy of divestment should be put into place . . . . . .'.

The speech read as follows-

Probably no threat to the global environment involves such widespread, serious and long lasting damage as the reduction in stratospheric ozone being brought about by the release of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) or freons. CFCs are a class of hydrocarbon chemicals in which some or all of the hydrogen atoms have been replaced with chlorine and fluorine.

History

CFCs were first synthesised in 1928 and came into use as refrigerant gases. They had an advantage over earlier gases being less toxic, non-flammable and apparently inert. In 1974 two US chemists, Molina and Rowland posed a simple question, `What had happened to the millions of tons of CFC which had been released in the previous 46 years?' The only `sink' they could hypothesise was the stratosphere where these otherwise stable compounds would be bombarded and degraded by the intense short wave ultra-violet (UV) light which comes from the sun. They quickly realised that if they were right, stratospheric breakdown of CFCs by UV would release atomic chlorine which would catalyse the destruction of ozone.

Ozone or O3 is the gas which protects the lower atmosphere and earth's surface from very damaging short wave UV. Rowland and Molina warned that this hypothetical model should be checked out, for if correct, the consequences for life on earth were serious indeed.

Studies were done and by 1976 the US National Academy of Science (NAS) was confirming these earlier predictions and recommending restrictions on the use of CFCs. In 1979 CFCs, which by then had come into very widespread use as pressure pack propellants, were banned from this application in the US, Canada, Sweden and Norway. Other countries, including Australia, continued to allow their use for this purpose. As well as continuing in use as refrigerant gases, throughout the 70s and 80s CFCs were used increasingly as the expanding gases in the manufacture of both rigid and soft plastic foams. Most recently CFCs have been extensively used as solvents for degreasing electronic chips.
Ozone Formation

The primitive earth's atmosphere contained large amounts of carbon dioxide and was reducing rather than oxidising. Consequently the earth's surface was not protected from short wave UV by a stratospheric ozone layer. Indeed, life possibly began through the action of UV light on molecules in a reducing environment. Thus life evolved in and remained in the seas for a long period. Water protected it from the sun's lethal UV radiation. Not until green plants produced oxygen by photosynthesis and some of this oxygen formed ozone in the stratosphere could plants and animals survive on dry land. The oxygen to ozone conversion occurs in the stratosphere and is also caused by UV.
Long Term Damage to Ozone

CFCs released at the earth's surface take about 5 years to rise through the atmosphere to the stratosphere where they catalyse ozone destruction. Once there the two freons in widest use (F11 and F12) remain in the stratosphere for between 75 and 150 years before being degraded and removed. The best available evidence shows between a 1% and 3% reduction in global stratospheric ozone in the last ten years, lower reductions near the equator, greater near the poles (Cicerone, 1987). In this 10 years ozone has been cut by 50% over the South Pole during spring.

In 1987 research in the Antarctic confirmed the presence of chlorine oxide, an active intermediate in the catalysis of ozone, and it is now widely accepted that the most probable cause of the Antarctic ozone hole is release of CFCs to the atmosphere.
While a number of chemical pathways have been hypothesised and many intermediates detected the major catalytic path may be summarised as:
Cl + O3 ClO + O2
ClO + O3 Cl + 2O2
Eventually chlorine is washed out by conversion to hydrochloric acid.
2Cl + H2O 2HClO 2HCl + O2

The enhanced ozone depletion in the Antarctic spring may be due to reactions involving chlorine nitrate and hydrochloric acid, catalysed by the presence of ice and nitric acid crystals in the stratosphere (Molina et al, 1987 and Tolbert et al, 1987).
Consequences

Short wave UV is destructive to all living cells causing damage to both DNA and proteins. It increases skin cancers and cataracts, changes immune responses and damages the laval forms of sea life that spend time in the top few millimetres of the seas. These organisms form the base of most aquatic food chains. Their destruction has the most serious consequences for all marine and fresh-water life. All other species suffer variable damage. A quantitative indication of consequences is given by the following: a 3% reduction in ozone gives about a 6% increase in relevant short wave UV which gives about a 12% increase in skin cancer (see numerous references in USEPA, UNEP Vol 1 Overview, 1986).

Ozone is a very selective filter of shorter wave UV, i.e., the most biologically active. A 10% reduction in stratospheric ozone gives a 20% increase in UV penetration of 305 nm, a 250% increase at 290 nm and a 500% increase at 287 nm. DNA and proteins absorb maximally at about 260 nm and 280 nm respectively. Frequencies in this region are particularly damaging. (nm = nanometre, a measure of wavelength)
(See figure 1.)

Because of CFC's long residence time in the stratosphere Hoffman of the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has calculated that ozone will continue to disappear unless CFC release is cut by 85% immediately and this 15% level or less is then maintained. This conclusion has been generally accepted by the scientific community.
Figures 2 & 3 are from Hoffman's paper in USEPA, UNEP Volume 1, Overview, 1986.

Although UV increase as a consequence of ozone destruction is the most immediate concern it should not be forgotten that CFCs are also very effective greenhouses gases, far more effective than carbon dioxide. Their role as greenhouse gases is only overshadowed by carbon dioxide because of the latter's much higher concentration in the atmosphere. Nonetheless while carbon dioxide will provide about 47% of the greenhouse warming between 1980 and 2030, CFCs will contribute as much as 27%. Moreover, while the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide is increasing at about 0.5% p.a., CFC 11 and 12 are increasing at 5 and 7% p.a. respectively. As shown in Figure 4, under the conditions of the Montreal Protocol, if all nations limit their production to 0.3 kg/head (and limit population to its present size) CFC 11 and 12 in the atmosphere would still increase sixfold over the next two centuries.
(See Figure 4.)
The Vienna Convention and the Montreal Protocol

For several years the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) has been bringing nations together to discuss this threat to the global ozone, the most recent meeting being in Montreal in late 1987. It was there agreed that a protocol will come into force on 1 January 1989. Six months later nations are to set CFC consumption at 1986 levels, between 1993 and 94 to cut consumption by 20% and by 1999 by 50%.
The 1986 production is calculated by multiplying the actual production of each freon by its Ozone Depleting Potential (ODP) and totalling the resulting figures.

Developing countries whose consumption of `controlled substances' (the term used in the protocol) is less than 0.3 kg per capita per year may delay their compliance with the control measures for up to 10 years provided their annual consumption does not exceed 0.3 kg per capita. For comparison, Australia's 1986 consumption was about 1.1 kg per capita.

1. An average Australian uses CFC at 45 times the rate of an average Chinese. This places a heavy personal responsibility on individual Australians to reduce their use of CFCs.

On the other hand China's population is very large and the absolute impact which China would have on the earth's ozone were she to adopt the pattern of CFC use found in the US and Australia would be enormous. It is therefore imperative that alternative technologies be found and implemented quickly.

Extending the Chinese example it should be noted that 1986 production/release was approximately 0.16 kg/head averaged over the whole planet. 1. CFC 11 and 12 contributed 13,100 (74%) of Australia's 1986 ozone depleting potential.
2. CFC 22 use in refrigerators and air conditioners was 26% of all CFC's used in refrigeration. The ODP of CFC 22 is very low.

3. Contribution by sector to Australia's 1986 ozone depleting potential: Aerosols 29%, Refrigeration and airconditioning 25%, Foams 19%, Solvent 4%, Halons 22% (the actual release of halons only contributed 2%)

4. Considering CFC alone the removal of CFCs from pressure packs, the exclusive use of CFC 22 in refrigerators and an 85% recycling of CFC used in foam manufacture and as solvents could cut the ozone depleting potential by 96.5%
As of April 1988 only the US and Mexico have ratified the Montreal Protocol.

Halons 1211 and 1301 are CF2BrC1 and CF3Br respectively. They are widel y used in fire extinguishers. The provision of an extinguisher is a precaution one hopes will never be needed. Therefore most of these halons will never be used. It is estimated that in 1986 only 30t of halons were actually released to the atmosphere. However in the absence from Australia of a high temperature incinerator to dispose safely of these stable and persistent chemicals and in view of their very high ozone depleting potential the halons must also be rapidly phased out of use. By the very nature of their application they cannot be recycled.
Too Little Too Late
Recognising that:
a. the Montreal Protocol falls far short of the 85% immediate reduction that is required. (Since 1986 actual ozone depletion has always exceeded computer predictions.)
b. the problems relates to CFC release to atmosphere, not in use
c. bringing in new gases and new technology in, say refrigeration, requires fairly long lead times,
on behalf of the Australian Democrats I introduced a motion in the Senate last year to achieve two things:
i. Eliminate the trivial and non essential uses of CFCs, i.e. in pressure packs.
ii. Insist on recycling of CFCs in all other applications.
Both Government and Opposition in speaking to this motion recognised that global ozone depletion caused by CFC release was the most important environmental problem.
References
1. Cicerone, Ralph J. `Changes in Stratospheric Ozone.' (1987) Science 237:35-42
2. Molina, Mario J. et al. `Antarctic Stratospheric Chemistry of Chlorine Nitrate, Hydrogen Chloride, and Ice: Release of Active Chlorine.' (1987) Science 238: 1253-57
3. Tolbert, Margaret A. et al. `Reactions of Chlorine Nitrate with Hydrogen Chloride and Water at Antarctic Stratospheric Temperatures.' (1987) Science 238:1258-60

4. USEPA, UNEP (1986) Volume 1: Overview ``Effects of changes in Stratospheric Ozone and Global Climate''. This, and its companion volumes contain a wealth of information. Several of the papers contained in this volume are referred to in the text.
The Bill

It is clear that much more needs to be done to reduce the release of ozone depleting substances than is incorporated in the Montreal Protocol. The Protocol specifically allows nations to proceed with CFC reduction faster than the mutually agreed 20% then 50% reduction by the end of the century. This is not only desirable it is both necessary and possible.

CFC use in pressure pack cans can not be defended and should be phased out quickly and completely. This is a non-essential use of CFC's. Twenty five percent of pressure packs on Australian shelves still contain CFC's. Trivial applications, such as use in cosmetics appear to be expanding in Australia. It would be disastrous if China were to follow this path! In all other applications CFC's could be recycled. When a refrigerator requires regassing or gets to the end of its life the CFC could and should be collected, cleaned and recycled. At present it is merely bled to the atmosphere.

Table 3 shows that freon 22 has an ozone depleting potential near to zero. CFC's with unsubstituted hydrogens appear to be much less stable. Replacing CFC 11 and 12 with CFC 22 in refrigerators (where possible) would substantially reduce the ODP.

If CFC's continue to be used in foam expansions and solve applications, these processes could and should be carried out in closed systems, the CFC sucked off, condensed and recycled. Already Unifoam AG, Glarus, Switzerland, a plastic foam manufacturer has developed a process which is achieving 85% recycling. (Modern Plastics International, November, 1987, p66).
There are foaming gases other than CFC's in widespread use. Hydrocarbons have been used extensively but, as with pressure packs, they pose a risk because of their flammability.

It's clear that our ultimate aim should be to eliminate CFC use entirely. However, with CFC's a part of so many aspects of our industrial life style this can not be achieved as quickly as necessary. The lead times for change are too long. But the achievement of 85%+ reduction is possible by elimination of unnecessary uses (pressure packs) and recycling in others.

1. The title of the Bill avoids reference to chlorofluorocarbons and uses the term ``Ozone Depleting Substances''. There are a number of non-chlorofluorocarbon substances which have ozone depleting characteristics, e.g. the 1,1,1,-trichloroethane used as a solvent in typist correcting fluid. At present these are not major contributors to ozone depletion. However the Bill leaves the way open to control the use and release of any of these agents should future research show that to be necessary.

2. The definition of ``ozone depleting substance'' (O.D.S.) in 3. (1) is in two parts. Part (a) adopts Group 1 of Annex A to the Montreal Protocol while part (b) allows the declaration of any other substance to be an O.D.S. It should be noted that part (a) does not include CFC 22 which has an ozone depleting potential of 0.03 compared with CFC 11 or 12 which have an ozone depleting potential of 1.0. As 26% of the CFC used in refrigerators in Australian in 1986 was CFC 22 rather than CFC 11 or 12, CFC 22 will almost certainly need eventual control. However, this Bill, which is designed to make the most rapid reduction in ODS release at the earliest opportunity, allows the uncontrolled use of CFC 22 to continue at present.

Halons are also not included at this stage. As mentioned earlier the ozone depleting potential of halons is large but, at the moment, release of halons is small. It is anticipated that halons will be quickly brought under this legislation but that twelve months, the ``period of grace'' allowed in this Bill, may be insufficient for the transition to alternatives for extinguishers. As the nature of their use precludes recycling of halons the only course open is total abandonment of their use.

3. The Bill sets a ``period of grace'' of twelve months after which the controls on substances, equipment and practices outlined in the Bill will become operative. The Bill contains no retrospective element with respect to equipment although, of course, bulk stocks of ODS's held at the end of the period of grace will become subject to control.
4. Clause 5 bans the use of ODS's in aerosols.

5. Clause 6 requires that all new refrigeration equipment, including air conditioners, be so constructed that contained ODS's can be collected, safely stored and recycled. Clause 8 requires that ODS's in equipment manufactured or sold after the end of the period of grace be collected and not allowed to escape when the equipment is serviced. Clause 9 requires that before disposal at the end of its useful life such equipment will be drained of its ODS's so that no ODS escapes to atmosphere.

6. Clause 7 covers other uses of ODS's such as foam blowing and solvent degreasing. It requires that these operations be carried out in closed systems in such a way that ODS vapours can be removed safely, stored and not allowed to escape to atmosphere.
Recognising that total recycling in such applications is clearly impossible, the clause sets a minimum of 85% efficiency in this recycling operation.

Both the major uses of ODS's covered by this clause are fairly large scale commercial operations for which the measurement of efficiency in recycling should be straightforward. In both applications there are non-CFC alternatives and some use of CFC 22.
I reiterate that equipment is available and in use in Switzerland for the manufacture of plastic foams which achieves an 85% efficiency of recycling of ODS's.

7. Clause 11 prohibits the exportation from Australia of equipment which does not conform to the new requirements imposed by this Bill. While Australia can have no control over the manner of use of this equipment in foreign hands, this requirement should act as an encouragement to behave responsibly.

8. Clause 10 controls the safe storage, transport and handling of ODS's. Once it becomes illegal to release ODS's to atmosphere those holding used ODS's collected from serviced or scrapped equipment or recycled solvent or foaming agents will have only two methods of disposing of these materials. Either they may be destroyed in a high temperature incinerator, which Australia does not yet possess, or they may be cleaned, redistilled and recycled into use. It is anticipated that this Bill will force this latter course.

In some quarters fears have been expressed that substantial diminution in CFC manufacture in Australia will lead to unemployment in that industry. Recycling of CFC's with a need to redistill or otherwise purify used, mixed or contaminated CFC almost certainly in the same facilities now involved in manufacture of CFC, will accommodate some of this potential unemployment.
9. Clauses 15-18 create the mechanisms for inspection by identifiable authorised persons of places and equipment and the taking and keeping of records.

10. Clause 21 enables the creation of regulations which require the keeping of records by appropriate persons and the specification of which records should be kept. Regulations will also require the labelling of refrigeration equipment and set the manner in which processes involving ODS's are to be carried out.

11. Clause 20 has the effect that the Bill will operate in relation to natural persons or bodies corporate who manufacture etc., in the course of or for the purposes of trade and commerce among the States and Territories or overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

That seems to be an ambiguity or an omission that needs to be clarified. In normal circumstances I think one would be justified in taking the view that great caution should be exercised before allowing evidence to be taken in public by a device. So I am simply seeking that the Senate authorise this move in no way as a precedent of the future and pending the clarification of the position on the matter.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to incorporate into that Act various excise tariff proposals tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings and early in this sittings.

These proposals concern the excise duty on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG); adjustments to the excise duties on refined petroleum products. Following movements in the import parity price; an increase in the Excise duty on aviation gasoline; and an adjustment to restrict the total excise duty increases as a result of consumer price index (CPI) indexations for the 1987-88 financial year to 6 per cent.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The excise duty for naturally occurring LPG is adjusted six-monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the Government's LPG excise policy announced in April 1980. The excise rate is calculated as 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne. The realised price is based on the weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the immediately preceding six months.

Before 30 June 1987 the Excise applied to LPG from all fields in production in August 1977. However, under the new petroleum excise arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987, LPG produced from onshore fields is exempt from excise, so the excise now only applies to offshore fields-that is, Bass Strait. No excise is payable on refinery-produced LPG.

Clause 3 of the Bill will amend the excise rate with effect from 1 October 1987, from $5.02 to $13.21 a kilolitre, an increase of $8.19 from the previous rate set on 1 April 1987. The increase reflects an increase in export prices of LPG in March 1987 and the stability of prices at the higher level for the six month period since then.
Import Parity Price adjustments
The import parity price adjustments for 1 October 1987 and 1 December 1987, at clauses 4 and 5, reflect movements in world oil prices during the respective preceding month.

The reduction in the import parity price for 1 October directly results in a decrease in excise and royalty receipts for crude oil, while the increase in the oil price for December will increase excise and royalty receipts.

Since March 1986, the Government's policy has been to fully offset changes in its revenue from crude oil excise and royalty by across-the-board changes in excises payable on petroleum products. The net result of this decision has been that, as crude oil prices change, government revenues remain the same overall.

Consistent with this Government's policy, excise rates on refined petroleum products were increased on 17 October 1987 and decreased on 15 December 1987. These changes are expected to be the final adjustments of this kind, as the Government has decided, with the deregulation of crude oil marketing from 1 January 1988, to discontinue the practice of offsetting changes in crude oil revenue by changes in product excise rates. In the absence of the import parity pricing mechanism from 1 January, a continuation of the practice would have been difficult and inappropriate in a free market environment. However, the Government will continue to monitor oil prices closely and will consider variations in petroleum product excise rates, to counter inflationary or revenue effects, in the case of a substantial change in world oil prices.
Aviation Gasoline

Clause 6 of the Bill will increase the amount of excise duty on aviation gasoline with effect from 1 January 1988, to cover the cost of terminal navigation-that is, air traffic control-and rescue and firefighting services at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston airports. Aircraft using Avgas ceased to be charged for those services with effect from the 1 January commencement date, and the additional charge of half a cent per litre will offset the cost of those services.

These revised arrangements were introduced after consultation with the aviation industry had revealed that, under the previous charging arrangements which came into effect last July, general aviation Avgas operators who used the three airports, and incurred landing charges as a result, were disadvantaged compared with their competitors operating at the general aviation secondary airports, who were not faced with any landing charges in respect of their use of those facilities. The extent of the disparity was not foreseen by either the industry or the Government at the time the changes were made last July.

The Government reconsidered the position of AVGAS excise charging arrangements in respect of these three airports following its consultations with the major industry associations, and the proposal to replace the Commonwealth's landing charges-that is, the terminal navigation and rescue and fire fighting service charges-at these airports with an additional 0.5c per litre surcharge on Avgas excise has been introduced to remove the disparity occasioned by the charges which users of these three airports were encountering.
Limitation of Excise Indexation to around 6 per cent
Clause 7 of the Bill will effectively limit the total excise indexation increases for the 1987-88 financial year to 6 per cent.

These amendments fulfil the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the inaugural Ruby Hutchison Memorial Address at the National Press Club on 13 March 1987. The amendments decrease the rates of excise duty applying immediately prior to indexation on the February 1988 adjustment date, so that when the legislative provisions for indexation are applied-which require the use of the published CPI-the resulting indexation is 2.5 per cent. This increase, when combined with the August 1987 indexation adjustment of 3.5 per cent, yields a total indexation of 6 per cent for the 1987-88 financial year.
Financial Impact Statement
(A) Liquefied petroleum gas:
The 1 October 1987 increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $9.5m in excise receipts in 1987-88;
(B) Import parity price:

The alterations in refined petroleum product excise rates due to the changes in the import parity prices effective from 17 October 1987 and 14 December 1987 are expected to have the following impact on revenue in 1987-88:
The increase in refined petroleum product excise rates effective 17 October 1987 is expected to increase revenue by about $121m; and
the decrease in refined petroleum product excise rates effective 14 December 1987 is expected to decrease revenue by about $66m.
These changes in the excise rates following the above changes to import parity prices are intended to exactly offset the forecast changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalties;
(C) Aviation gasoline surcharge:

The measure has no direct financial implications, as it has been designed only to recover the revenue which will be forgone by the Commonwealth as a result of the removal of the terminal navigation and rescue and firefighting components of the landing charges levied at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston airports; aircraft using aviation gasoline ceased to be charged for these services from 1 January 1988, the date of effect of the surcharge;
(D) Limitation of total excise indexation to 6 per cent
The financial impact of imposing a 6 per cent ceiling on excise duty rate increases for 1987-88 is estimated to result in revenue forgone of $25m for that financial year.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1987 INCOME TAX (OFFSHORE BANKING UNITS) (WITHHOLDING TAX RECOUPMENT) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. The purpose of the first Bill is to amend the income tax laws in various ways, particularly the Income Tax Assessment Act. (Quorum formed) The Hawke Government has brought in more taxation Bills and imposed more taxes on this nation than any other government in our history. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill, which is complementary to the first Bill, are not opposed by the Opposition. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) will amend various taxation laws to give effect to a range of policy decisions of the Government. The more important amendments to be made relate to the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. They include measures to encourage the development of offshore banking in Australia through a withholding tax exemption for interest paid to non-residents by offshore banking units. Capital gains tax roll-over relief is being given for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts. There are amendments to correct certain deficiencies in the taxation of lump sum superannuation and similar payments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will also remove special concessional treatment for expenditure on buildings for scientific research or other research or development purposes and on the development of certain computer software. Other amendments include further concessions to permit shelf companies to satisfy common ownership tests contained in the income tax law, modifications to thin capitalisation provisions and measures to extend the coverage of the income tax law to a range of activities in offshore areas and external territories. There are also a number of technical amendments to correct anomalies and deficiencies in the taxation law. In other words, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) is a highly technical Bill. It contains some points of principle which, as I have said, the Opposition does not object to.

The complementary Bill-the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill-will give effect to the Government's decision, announced on 1 July 1986 and expanded in April last year, to provide an interest withholding tax exemption to facilitate offshore banking in Australia primarily for dealings in foreign currencies with non-residents. It will apply to interest and payments in the nature of interest paid by offshore banking units on specified borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986. To preserve our national withholding tax base and in recognition of the practicalities of tracing and monitoring the application of particular borrowings, any misapplication of funds that attract the concession provided is to bear a special income tax rate-a penal rate-of 300 per cent. That penal rate will be imposed by way of the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill.

Whilst not opposing the Bills, the Opposition will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading to highlight the general taxpayer's total dissatisfaction with the heavy burden of the Government's taxation policies. It is not only a heavy and onerous burden but one which is becoming increasingly heavy and onerous as the Government inexorably takes an ever-increasing share of our total national product in taxation year by year. I will be circulating an amendment along the following lines:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue-
I note that that is a Budget estimate; the latest figures for the first eight months of this year suggest that that figure will be well exceeded-
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax;
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes-
that point is worthy of emphasis-

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living''.

This proposed amendment contains some very important points that must be got across to the Australian electorate. The electors know the net effect of those points, and that net effect is that Australians are being hurt, and hurt increasingly, as a result of the policies of this Government. More and more throughout this Government's five years in office it has become the highest taxing government in Australia's history. That burden has fallen on every Australian. There has been some suggestion in Australian Labor Party circles that the reason the electorate has swung so massively against Labor in seats like Adelaide, Port Adelaide and Groom, as well as in the New South Wales State election and State by-elections in Victoria and Western Australia, is that Labor has failed to communicate its message to the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has communicated it all right.

—As Senator Reid quite rightly points out, it has communicated its message effectively; the problem is that the message communicated is one that the Australian elect- orate can no longer tolerate. That is why it is turning away from the Hawke Government and from the Labor Party in ever-increasing numbers. The simple message is that the Australian public can no longer tolerate and live with the continual attacks on its living standards that have been the hallmark of this Government. It is almost unbelievable that 25 per cent or more of our total gross domestic product this year will be collected in tax revenue. The Government talks about the need to increase productivity and restore competitiveness to the Australian economy. It seems to find only one way to do that. It seems to believe that, if we allow the exchange rate to depreciate far enough, somehow continual depreciation will solve our problems. What it ignores absolutely and totally is the fact that unless we give people and businesses, small and large, an opportunity, a reason and an incentive to work, produce and grow, living standards will inevitably fall.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing that is happening in this economy in terms of Government policies is designed to pursue that essential course. Coupled with an absolute mishmash of fiscal policy, wages policy and external policy in a way that is totally inconsistent with the needs of the Australian economy in the longer term, that is why Australia's productivity is abysmally low. That is why this financial year, 1987-88, productivity in this country will actually fall-at a time when the future of our country depends essentially on an increase in productivity because that is the only way, in an increasingly competitive world, that we can grow and maintain, let alone increase, our living standards. The Government's policies, particularly but not exclusively in the area of taxation, are seemingly designed to frustrate that essential requirement.

A $5.5 billion increase in taxation this year-an increase in excess of 8 per cent-at a time when the whole thrust of policy must be to reduce the burden of tax, is perhaps the most stark demonstration that one can give of the inadequateness and in appropriateness of the Government's policies in terms of total tax collections. But when we look at the Government's savage attacks through increases in consumption taxes, the position becomes of even more concern. Sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster in terms of its revenue take than any other of the Government's taxes. So far this financial year sales tax collections in Australia have risen by 18 per cent. That is three times faster than this year's forecast inflation rate and it is even faster than the huge 14 1/2 per cent rise in the total income tax take to be collected this year. Since the Hawke Government came to office sales tax collections have increased by 110 per cent. They have more than doubled in the five years since this Government came to office, to a yearly rate of $7.5 billion. That rise in sales tax represents almost three times the rate of inflation and double the increase in Australian wages, salaries and other benefits under the Hawke Government.

Those figures, coupled with the increases that have occurred in the income tax burden of average Australian families, demonstrate very clearly the enormous problems that families in this country have in staying above the breadline. An increasing number of them are living below the proverty line. There are now three-quarters of a million more Australians living below the proverty line than there were when this Government came to office. That is, 750,000 more Australians are living in poverty now than was the case in 1983.

Let us look at the effect this Government's taxation policy has had on family income earners. Let us take a single income family on average weekly earnings. The average tax rate that that family paid in March 1983, when this Government came to office, was 17 1/2 per cent. By July last year it was 20 1/2 per cent. In that time the Government's marginal tax rate went up from 30 per cent to 40 per cent. In numerical terms, tax payments went up from $65 a week in March 1983 to $102 a week in July of last year. Taking into account the December 1986 and July 1987 so-called tax cuts-and they were nothing of the sort in real terms-single income earners and families are now paying 42 per cent and 57 per cent more tax respectively than when the Hawke Labor Government came to power in 1983. Even though that is cold and stark statistical information, it is a very clear demonstration of what has happened to the choices that individuals might otherwise have been able to make and the ability of families, particularly those around and below the average weekly earnings level, to bear those increases.

Putting it another way, for a single income family on average weekly earnings the tax burden has increased in the last five years by 95 per cent in contrast to an increase in wages of about 40 per cent. Increasing numbers of Australians are moving into the higher income tax bracket and now a substantial proportion of the full time work force is paying 40c in the dollar rather than something like 30c in the dollar. In effect, the basic standard rate tax applicable to the full time work force has been increased under this Government by 25 per cent. Indeed, it has increased from 30c to 40c in the dollar-a one-third increase.

Company tax has moved in a similar direction. At a time when the Government has been talking about reducing the burden on companies and making them more competitive in an increasingly competitive world, it has increased company tax from 46c in the dollar to 49c. That trend in corporate taxation policy is completely opposite to that which has occurred in virtually every other country in the western world. I think I am correct in saying that there is almost no other country in the western world-there would be few exceptions-in which the corporate tax rate is higher than it is in Australia. I will come back to the point, because it should never be overlooked, that we are in a world which is becoming increasingly competitive, increasingly interdependent, and if we do not pursue domestic policies which will enable our producers to compete on an equal footing with the rest of the world we will slide increasingly down the scale of real living standards. That slide has been occurring progressively over the years, and the five years of the Hawke Government have accentuated it.

That is why the people of Australia are hurting, that is why they are rejecting the Labor Government. Despite all the hype and the rhetoric, the net result of this Government's policies has been more hurt, hurt, hurt to the low and average income earners and families of this nation. The increasing tax take has been carried out in a totally dishonest manner. Appropriate adjustments have not been made to the income tax rates to take account of the inflation boosted increases in money wages, and that has pushed people progressively into higher tax brackets-what is known as bracket creep.

We, as a nation, face a very fragile and uncertain future. The economic outlook in this country and internationally is still more fraught with danger than it has been in virtually any postwar period. One has only to look at Australia's balance of payments to get the most striking example of our fragility. There is great talk by the Government about our balance of payments situation having improved in recent months. I do not deny that the current account deficit has, on trend, been decreasing. But we are talking about a decrease from a deficit ranging up to $1 1/2 billion per month, to figures which vary from month to month between about $500m and $800m.

That might be a movement in the right direction, but we are still faced with an absolutely enormous, intolerable and totally unsustainable balance of payments situation. This year the current account deficit-the amount we buy from the rest of the world compared with what we sell to it-will again be about $11 billion to $12 billion. Therefore, our external debt is growing at the rate of about a billion dollars per month. It is no wonder that in the five years since the Hawke Government came to office, our debt to the rest of the world has quadrupled. When Mr Hawke became Prime Minister in March 1983, our debt to the world was about $28 billion. Today that debt in gross terms is approximately $112 billion, and in net terms it is about $84 billion, as we have mentioned in the proposed amendment to the second reading motion. Those figures are not only staggering; they are the very reason why virtually every economist and businessman in Australia says that our economy is unsustainably fragile.

There is another aspect of that debt burden which has not received a lot of attention as yet but which adds to that fragility and concern. In 1983, of all our foreign debt to the rest of the world, 8.2 per cent had a maturity date of less than 12 months. By 1986 that figure had risen to 24 per cent; almost one quarter of our total debt had a maturity date of less than 12 months. In the last year or so, 90 per cent of all new foreign borrowings have been for periods of less than one year. With a situation like that, the slightest downturn in the world economy and in terms of our external situation, and any dint to confidence internationally, can have a profound effect on the situation here.

What we need to be doing is shoring up our position to cope with the vagaries and uncertainties of a very uncertain international economic climate. The forecasters of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and those elsewhere in the world are almost universally predicting a slowdown of growth in the world economy in 1989, probably starting later this year. That slowdown may well have a profound effect on the prospects for the Australian economy because our prospects depend so essentially on our ability to sell overseas. If the rest of the world is not buying from us in the same order of magnitude, because of its slower economic growth, the significance for the Australian economy is profound.

We should be adopting policies to take account of those uncertainties in the period ahead and also putting ourselves in a position of productivity and competitiveness that will enable us to take the advantages that exist today in many areas of the world economy and hopefully in the years ahead. Unless this Government realises that the essential prerequisite for that to occur is a reduction in the overall tax burden-not just a shuffling of the tax burden from one part to another, but getting a reduction in the total tax burden which can be achieved only by fiscal restraint of a nature that this Government seems incapable of producing-the prospect for this country, which should be great and bright and one of full opportunity for the future, will be frustrated and lost and people will continue to hurt as they have hurt and bled badly in the last five years. The policies of this Government must be changed immediately. In respect of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 will be the subject of the majority of my remarks but, of course, we are in an allied debate on the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. The first of those Bills introduces a withholding tax exemption for interest paid to non-residents by offshore banking units. The aim is to encourage the development of offshore banking in Australia. The legislation also extends roll-over relief; that is, deferral of liability from capital gains tax for certain reorganisations of resident units trusts. It also implements measures announced on 12 January 1987 to amend the taxation status of certain eligible termination payments, especially deferred annuities.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to note that this legislation will be voted on more than a year after the Press release announced that changes would be made to the taxation of deferred annuities. This is yet another reminder of the problems created by government that legislates by Press release. This Bill will close a loophole which allowed persons who were not dependants to receive superannuation and other termination payments tax free on the death of a taxpayer. Death benefits paid after 12 January 1987 will be exempt from the tax only if paid to dependants. With regard to deferred annuities, the Bill will introduce a range of measures to ensure that annuities purchased with roll over eligible termination payments do not qualify for tax concessions unless they provide genuine retirement incomes for the taxpayer and dependants. The Government tells us that there will be a revenue gain of some $30m in a full year.

The Australian Democrats acknowledge that these changes present some problems to people who have recently purchased variable income annuities. Again we point to problems with this sort of change in legislation which arise given a time gap between an announcement and legislation-problems which the industry and individuals attempting to plan their financial arrangements have found. But the need for governments to take this sort of action must be seen in the context of statistics, particularly from the Economic Planning Advisory Paper (EPAC) entitled Economic Effects of an Ageing Population, which was released on 1 February this year. Some of those statistics include the facts that the proportion of our population aged 65 years and over has increased from 4 per cent in 1901 to 10.5 per cent in 1986 and is projected to reach 16 per cent by the year 2025 and that the proportion of people aged under 15 has fallen from 35 per cent in 1901 to 23 per cent in 1986 and is projected to decline by 19 per cent by the year 2025.

The benefits of superannuation tax concessions accrue largely to the better off sections of the population. Only 15 per cent of employees earning less than $280 a week in 1986 had superannuation cover, compared with more than 70 per cent of people earning $520 or more. Tax concessions given to the superannuation industry have been estimated to cost over $3 billion. It is worth looking in some detail at other aspects of the provision and impact of superannuation because this is an issue on which we should be spending some time, when the Parliament is grappling with the provision of financial support for an increasingly ageing population.

The superannuation funds argue that with this ageing population superannuation concessions must be maintained to avoid a massive increase in social security pension payments to the aged. This is the challenge. However the question really is whether the current concessions give all Australians an equal chance to retire comfortably without receiving social security payments. At present, superannuation coverage is greatest for males, full-time workers, government employees and people with high incomes. The Social Security Review discussion paper Occupational Superannuation Arrangements in Australia found that in August 1986 only 3.1 per cent of employees earning under $120 per week were covered, compared with 71.7 per cent of those earning $520 a week or more.

Going back to the EPAC report, it found that superannuation concessions would contribute $54,000 to the retirement lump sum received by a person earning the then average weekly earnings-which was a little over $22,000-for the next 30 years compared with $123,000 for an individual receiving twice that income. We should recognise that for low income people current consumption is always likely to be a higher priority than saving through superannuation. Even if they wanted it to be a priority, hand to mouth existence would make that impossible. In 1982, fewer than 6 per cent of retirees received lump sums of more than $75,000. In 1986, 49.2 per cent of all male employees, but only 25.2 per cent of all female employees, were covered by current employer-arranged superannuation. Among managers and administrators the number of women with superannuation is particularly low. When we add to that the fact that the number of women in those positions is particularly low, that exacerbates the inequity. In 1986, 21,100 females had employer-sponsored superannuation in that sector compared with 185,100 males.

In 1986, 7 per cent of all part time employees were covered, compared with 46.5 per cent of all full time employees. This is a particular concern when we recognise that one of the major growth areas of employment is part time employment. Young people and mature aged women, because of the labour market oriented policies of the Government which have reduced access to social security benefits for a great many of them, are finding their way, if they are lucky, into the paid work force through part time work. Given the changes in employment patterns-part time work is becoming a greater feature-it is, of course, an enormous challenge to raise that level of superannuation cover for part time employees, if we are looking at any sort of system of equity in terms of retirement incomes.

In 1986 only 16.8 per cent of salespersons were covered, compared with almost 60 per cent of managers and administrators. At the top levels of management, executives with an average salary of $300,000 a year before retirement are eligible to receive a lump sum payout of $2.1m. Such executives have an incentive to receive their salary as payment into a superannuation fund, which is not taxed, rather than as income, which is taxed. The Australian Financial Review printed a supplement for those people entitled `Setting up a Million Dollar Nest Egg'. The first sentence of the article is very revealing:
For the executive with foresight superannuation offers a chance to make one salary dollar do the work of two.

On the one hand highly paid executives can arrange to contribute sums of over $100,000 a year to a superannuation fund, giving themselves a tax benefit and reducing their employers' on-costs-workers compensation, payroll tax, holiday pay, and so on. A self-employed person, on the other hand, receives a tax deduction for only the first $1,500 that he contributes to a superannuation fund. Of course, this is a major disadvantage for many small businesses.

According to EPAC, most superannuation benefits are taken as lump sums, not as annuities. Furthermore, most lump sums are presently taken by persons who retire early and very often are dissipated by the time, or very soon after, those people reach pension age. It is quite clear from the EPAC study why it is the case that women, in particular, are not very well covered by superannuation. It is a function of the inherent discrimination and inequities which still exist in work patterns. I referred to the figures regarding salespersons as opposed to managers and administrators. It is purely and simply a fact that, while more women are entering the paid work force, the distribution of women within the paid work force is still in the lower paid areas, not in the decision making, managerial, administrative areas. Their superannuation cover is, as a consequence, much lower.

This legislation attempts to address some of the issues in a very minor way. The big issues of what happens regarding superannuation are still before us. The Democrats acknowledge that, in those provisions of the legislation, the Government is going some way towards tidying up some of the loopholes. Certainly, we place on the record our concern for equity within the system. We support a national portable contributory superannuation scheme. We recognise that that is some distance down the track. But those issues of equity, in the decisions that we will make regarding further moves by Government in this area, will always be at the top of our agenda.

Other measures in this legislation cause us some concern-in particular, the measure which extends the eligibility of shelf companies to take advantage of tax minimisation concessions. The Democrats have been alone in opposing these sorts of systems which are still available to the corporate sector. Last time this type of provision was before us we attempted to amend it. The unholy alliance of Labor, Liberal and National parties defeated that amendment. It seems to have become an exercise in futility for the Australian Democrats to attempt to do anything which will reduce the rip-offs that are available to the corporate sector.

It is very interesting, in the context of the tax debate-and, since we are debating two taxation Bills, it is extremely relevant-to look at what is happening. I will give some indication as to the reasons why the Australian Democrats will not support the second reading amendment of the Opposition, an amendment which refers to the Government being a high taxing government, incentives, the need to invest and work productively, and so on. Neither the Opposition nor the Government is really attacking, as I say, what amounts to a corporate tax rip-off. We have, as I believe Senator Short pointed out, reached a situation where personal taxpayers are shouldering more of the tax burden. Nobody can disagree with that; it is a matter of record. What we should do about it is really the issue. The income tax share of total tax receipts rose from 34.3 per cent in 1965 to 45.1 per cent in 1985, while at the same time the corporate tax share fell from 16.2 per cent to only 9.2 per cent over the same period. Measures such as those contained in this legislation to which I have referred do not help.

I totally endorse the headline of an editorial in the dear departed Times on Sunday of 9 August 1987 which read `Corporate tax avoidance a major scandal'. I remind the Senate-it ought to need no reminding-of what is happening in that area. The statistics which I will cite are taken from an article, whose headline I heartily agree with, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 31 October 1987, headed `Why we desperately need the Government's tax review'. I must say that I was enormously relieved that the tax review continued subsequent to the stock market crash.

I recall that at that time I and some other politicians-and, to their credit, some Australian Labor Party backbenchers-pushed for a wealth inquiry in Australia. I recall that during the weeks after the stock market crash people were virtually saying, `Well, we don't need a wealth inquiry now; the poor things hardly have any money left'. I assume that we were supposed to feel sympathy for someone whose wealth may have dropped from, say, $17m to about $7m. I did not share that sympathy. At least the Government has gone ahead with its tax review. If the corporate tax review is properly conducted, it seems to me that it will answer many of the questions which were being asked by those of us who believe that we need an inquiry into wealth in Australia-subsequently that issue has been taken up by the Roman Catholic Church; I am very pleased to see that that is happening-and reveal some of the issues surrounding the accumulation of wealth in Australia and the maldistribution of income in this country.

Some statistics in the Sydney Morning Herald deal with this matter. I do not have with me the statistics for the year before last, but I do know that in that year the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd was able to manage to pay more than one per cent in tax, but in the last financial year it was able to pay only 0.18 per cent in tax. That was the lowest corporate tax payment among Australian companies.

It is interesting to look at the list of the lowest taxpayers among companies. Industrial Equity Ltd is mentioned in the list as paying 4.08 per cent in tax. It is interesting that Westfield Capital Corporation paid 4.24 per cent; Northern Star Ltd, 4.40 per cent; and News Ltd, 12.22 per cent. These companies are all part of a certain industry-the media industry. They are having a fairly good time at the moment at the hands of the Government. Of course, the Opposition is keeping very quiet about it at the moment. The Bond Corporation, which is also in that industry, paid 8.95 per cent in tax. Yet the corporate sector is screaming about disincentives. It is screaming, `We aren't able to be competitive', and, `This is a high taxing government.' But as far as it is concerned, that is just a myth. That is why the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer and, I might add, people on social security pensions and benefits-people dependent on the community as a whole for any income at all-are in fact paying out more by way of tax, or effective tax in the case of social security beneficiaries. We should recognise that, because of the low level of the tax threshold, even aged pensioners with minimal extra income, usually from a meagre investment of their total life savings or an investment representing their total life's work, are at the moment having to pay tax at a very early stage after they receive some additional income. These are issues which are not addressed by measures such as that to extend the eligibility of shelf companies which can then get involved in transfer pricing, which is one of the measures available to companies to enable them to fall so far below their actual 49 per cent tax rate.

We hear that Australia is a country which is highly taxed. However, once social security levies are borne in mind and excluded, Australian companies actually enjoy the second lowest tax burden of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. The only other country in which overall corporate taxes are lower is Turkey. It is for this sort of reason that we really cannot support the attachment by the Opposition. I have not mentioned in my list of corporate non-taxpayers Elders IXL Ltd, the company headed by John Elliott. We should note that that company not only is doing well, but is also doing well in comparison with the past. Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd in 1981, when it was still a pastoral industry based company with a net profit after tax of $34m, paid more tax than the newly-restructured Elders IXL did recently when it had a net profit after tax of $209m. The extension of eligibility in the area of transfer pricing in this legislation really is one issue about which we are very unhappy.

I would like also to mention something else which has not attracted either any action by the Government or negative attention from the Opposition but which has cost Australian taxpayers a lot of money in recent times. I refer to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) takeover madness. One would not particularly want to single out just one company.
