The whole issue of takeovers and the negative gearing available to corporations on their overseas borrowings is one which is costing us all dearly and about which nothing is being done. I might add that takeovers characterised as investment, which is mentioned in the Opposition's attachment, are certainly not productive investment.

The BHP takeover issue was thoroughly canvassed by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Haines, at the beginning of February this year. She pointed out that the series of transactions that have taken place added probably over $9 billion to Australia's overseas debt and have cost the taxpayer $680m in revenue. Bell and its associated companies have been buying BHP shares since 1983. Assuming an average cost to Bell of $8 a share, its recent holdings of some 466 million BHP shares in January 1988 would have cost the Bell group approximately $3.7 billion. Elders paid $1.7 billion for BHP shares in April 1986. Of course, this deal was to counter the Holmes a Court push. In the same deal BHP purchased $1.2 billion worth of Elders shares. It is all rather incestuous, is it not? In January 1988 there was the announcement which required BHP to spend at least $2.8 billion to buy back BHP shares from Bell and Elders. And on it goes.

It is this kind of exercise which is not being addressed, which, as I say, is costing Australian taxpayers a great deal of money, and which is increasing our foreign debt, about which we are all concerned. Unless something is done in regard to these sorts of moves we will continue to face an enormous foreign debt. What concerns the Australian Democrats is the way in which that problem of our foreign debt, and of taxation issues generally, is approached by both of the majority conservative parties in this place.

Perhaps the latest of the rather amazing exercises in that area is, of course, the renewed debate on a consumption tax. The arguments are all there. I must say that I am aghast at the gall of the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott, in presenting himself as the leading proponent of the introduction of a consumption tax. When we look at the situation in regard to his corporate entity and his corporate colleagues and the impact they are having on our foreign debt, which they use as an argument for restructuring our taxation situation, it seems to me-and words almost fail me-to be quite extraordinary that someone in that position should be promoting such a tax which is totally regressive and which impacts with most damage on the low income people in our community.

Some of those people, including Michael Short in the Melbourne Age yesterday, argue in favour of a consumption tax. In the first of the Melbourne Age series of articles on consumption tax Michael Short said.
Adjustments in the social security system can easily compensate the poor.

That is an argument which is so full of holes that it carries no water; certainly those people who are on social security benefits can be identified-and goodness knows where the proponents of this tax think the Government will get the money from-and perhaps they could be compensated. They would have a special card or, again, maybe a tattoo on their foreheads so that they could line up in the poverty line and be compensated! I question the morality of that sort of approach. However, there is an enormous sector of hidden poor in our community. That is beginning to be recognised. Low income people in the paid work force, particularly single income families with children-and the more children, the more difficulty-are difficult to identify as poor, because poverty involves more than simply the amount of money that comes into a household or into an individual's hands. Poverty is determined by far more factors than that.

Just last weekend the Institute of Family Studies held what I believe was a very successful and important two-day conference in Melbourne addressing the issue of children in poverty and raising these very important issues about the poor in our community. One of the key features of that two-day conference was the recognition that poverty extends through a wide range of people's experience and impacts on people in a number of ways and that it is more than simply the amount of money listed as income for a family or individual. Poverty is also related to their access to community infrastructure supports such as education, health, transport, child care and community services generally.

At that conference, at which there was presented a series of very important papers which I would urge all in this Parliament to look at closely, there emerged the recognition that for a great many people, in particular children but not only children-although the majority of these people are women and their children-the lack of access to public education, child care, health, transport and community services generally or, if they have access, the very low level of such facilities and the inability of those public services to serve their needs because of funding cut-backs or because of lack of commitment by the community, or by the Government representing the community, to high quality in those areas means that they are more disadvantaged, even though they may appear not to be below the Henderson poverty line or any other poverty line.

When one adds together all the disadvantages that exist in the community one sees that a great many people are disadvantaged. For them the outrageous suggestion of a consumption tax would be the last straw. We need to recognise that it is these people-the number is growing, to our great discredit-for whom the consumption tax is insupportable. We have to realise that consumption means spending. Almost 100 per cent of the spending of these people is on essentials such as food, clothing, shelter and transport-the very necessities that they need to conduct their daily lives. For the John Elliotts of this world a consumption tax would simply mean that their families or their colleagues would have to cough up only a little more cash, not only for the essentials of their lives but also for their luxuries.

It is interesting to see where everybody stands in this debate. This tax should be rejected out of hand as the Australian Democrats reject it out of hand. It is totally regressive. There can be no moral basis whatsoever for it. Whenever this debate arises in this chamber and on other occasions it is rather sickening to hear members of the Opposition complaining about the current sales tax regime and saying that we should not have tax on juice and milk and all those things. However, when those things were taxed in the Budget they were the ones who sat with the Government and allowed those taxes to be implemented, against the lone voice of the Australian Democrats. We stand firm against that sort of iniquitous taxation. We do now and we always will because we understand that there are hidden poor out there in the community and we are not prepared to go with the John Elliotts of this world against those people who are struggling in a hand to mouth existence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two Bills, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. They are essentially patch up Bills. What we are seeking to do today is to get something partially right which the Government has previously got manifestly wrong. The title of those Bills acknowledges that there have been mistakes. the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987 are, by their titles, manifestations of the previous mistakes of this Labor Government. What we have before us is merely bandaid treatment to patch up something which has gone wrong. If the Australian Labor Party listened to some of the debates and read some of the reactions in the newspapers to the legislation it proposes it would not get it so wrong and legislation such as that before the chamber today would not be necessary. It puts taxpayers in great difficulties when legislation is passed which is incomplete and inaccurate and which has unintended consequences. The legislation we are dealing with today acknowledges the haphazard approach to the preparation of tax laws by the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Taxation laws in Australia, unfortunately, have become intolerably complex. The legislation before the Senate today is an acknowledgment that the labyrinth of legislation is continuing to grow at an alarming rate. Let me give some of the figures. At the beginning of 1985-86 the Income Tax Assessment Act had grown to almost 1,500 pages from only 81 pages when the Act came into force. Not only has the legislative content increased but also the taxes on the ordinary person, including the lower income earner, have risen at unacceptably high rates to such an exorbitant level that the ordinary working men are now deserting the Labor Party in droves because of the taxation imposed upon their pockets. Keating's hand is in the ordinary working man's pocket.

Let me give an example. Only a few weeks ago when I was talking to a shearer he was complaining about the high tax rates. In fact, he was advocating a move towards a flatter rate of taxation, Madam Acting Deputy President-something that your husband had been advocating some time ago. I do not necessarily go 100 per cent along the way of a single flat tax but we do need lower rates of income tax. This shearer said, `Mate, I can no longer afford to vote for the Labor Party'. So the backbone of the Australian Labor Party, the Australian shearing movement, has a representative saying that he can no longer afford to vote for the Australian Labor Party because of its taxation policies, because Keating's hand is now so deep into all their pockets.
I think the legislation should be so written that it can be understood by the ordinary person in the community, but this is not the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you understand--

—I would challenge Senator Ray, with all his intelligence, to explain a few provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I defy him, with his intelligence, not to have difficulty comprehending some of the changes. I will give some examples for him to respond to later in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of the Tax Summit back in 1985 there was a lot of enthusiasm for the Tax Summit, tax reform and simplified income tax laws. In fact ideas of dramatic changes to the Australian taxation system and a simpler tax system that more Australians could understand were warmly applauded at the time, and rightly so. I remind the Senate that here we have another area of broken promises because three years down the track all we have is an intricate and ambiguous system of taxation that ordinary Australians cannot hope to comprehend. But what they do know is that they are paying more tax than they did then. Time and again the Liberal-National Party Opposition has had cause to condemn the Labor Party because of its attitude in creating a maze of taxation legislation which is excessively complex.

Let me remind the Senate of a few statistics. Between January and December of last year innumerable tax Bills, amounting to hundreds and hundreds of pages of new legislation, were brought before the Parliament. This meant more and more taxes and the deeper and deeper Keating's hand went into all our pockets. Yet today we are again faced with another package of Bills that include over 20 significant amendments-change upon change. We are looking down the barrel of yet another year of Mr Keating's so-called tax reforms to make the system more complex, whereby the ordinary person cannot hope to understand it. The Labor Party is at least starting to acknowledge that company taxes are too great. There is a lot of money that should be invested in Australia but, since we have about the highest corporate tax rates in the world, the funds are staying out there when they could quite well be used productively here.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish and you know it. It is one of the lowest in the world.

—I ask Senator Maguire to say what the Government is going to do. It is going to tax superannuation funds to fund reductions in company tax. It is quite immoral to do that simply to reduce the tax burden of the corporate sector. It would be taking the money from one entity, the ordinary individuals who plan long term savings and put money into superannuation, in order just to give the companies much needed tax relief. That is quite immoral and that is the whole approach of the Government's discussion in relation to so-called tax reform. No wonder the ordinary working person, the ordinary Australian, is rebelling against its taxation reform.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, we are faced with 20 significant amendments to legislation. The Government has set the ball rolling. Keating has started the so-called softening up process. It is true that company tax rates are far too high. There is a need to reduce the company tax burden from the current 49 per cent, but the Government's methods of financing such a reduction are quite corrupt. Such statements as the Government has been making only cause further damage to sound investment programs which are so vital and necessary to the recovery of the Australian economy.

We speak of high taxation rates under this Government. Already under this Hawke Labor Government we pay more tax as a proportion of the rewards for the Australian productive effort than we have ever paid before. That is very significant. What has that meant? It has meant a high cost of living for ordinary, average wage earners. It is not surprising that there is a constant demand out there in the community-a community which is ignored by this Australian Labor Party Government-for lower and lower taxes. We must protect the standard of living and bring about a significant restructuring and lowering of taxes in Australia.

Recently I have noted with interest that a correspondent from the Australian Taxation Office has brought out a sparkling new slogan-`Taxes-building a better Australia'. In other words, higher taxes. Here again is another manifestation from an arm of government-the Australian Taxation Office-acknowledging the Labor Party's philosophy that higher taxes are better for the people and better for Australia. The ordinary working man says that this is not the case. The ordinary working man says that not only has the Taxation Office got it wrong, but also the Australian Labor Party has got it wrong. Higher taxes do not necessarily build a better Australia if they reduce the living standards and the disposable incomes of ordinary people, who cannot afford to pay. I think that it is quite intolerable. I believe that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) should start talking about rewriting the income tax Act in order to make it work more efficiently and so that it is more understandable. The tax Act is now riddled with so many unintended consequences. One is required to refer not only to the Act but to a whole myriad of regulations and rulings put out by the Australian Taxation Office.

These Bills are an attempt to try to patch up some of the difficulties. The amendments before us testify to the inability of those who attempted to frame the laws in the first place-that is, this Labor Government-to get them right. There are now in excess of 2,500 taxation rulings and that is in addition to the 1,500 pages of complex income tax legislation. More and more people have to pay more and more money to tax accountants just to find out what is going on. Even the professionals have trouble in isolating the true meaning of the law. Senator Robert Ray is not alone in his problems of comprehending some of the intricate details, because even the tax professionals cannot understand the myriad of details. We have to look beyond the tax law, the case law, the regulations and so on.

Let me give the Senate a fairly simple example. A lot of people invest in what are known as 10-year investment bonds. Because of the changes in negative gearing and so on, it is possible to finance this through negative gearing. We all know that if the bond remains invested for 10 years, it is cashed tax free. If it is cashed earlier, there is a taxation element. This is commonly understood by those investing in such bonds and such investment is a commonplace practice. Unfortunately, neither the tax accountants nor the Taxation Office can say whether the interest paid on this negatively geared financial arrangement is tax deductible. So common are the problems in the implementation of our highly complex laws that the Taxation Office has again found it necessary recently to establish a `problem resolution program'. That in itself is a mouthful. This program has been established within the Taxation Office so that one section of that Office can liaise with another section on behalf of those hundreds of thousands of taxpayers who are now desperately in trouble because they cannot understand and do not know what the law is. As a result of this situation they are paying penalties. I am sure that everyone in this chamber and everyone who is listening to this debate has some experience of the long waits and problems in this area of taxation.

One of my constituents, whose accounts for the 1986-87 period have been recently subjected to a taxation audit, has yet to receive his assessment for three years earlier. I must say that I do not like this approach. If the Australian Taxation Office is going to investigate, it should investigate; if it is going to audit, it should do so. It should not leave people hanging, waiting for up to three years before they can find out what is happening. Another small-businessman had to wait up to six months between an official notification from the Taxation Office that he would be audited and the time that the job was eventually done. That is not a particularly good situation to be in. In the interim such people are prevented from making many decisions which are necessary for their survival in the business world as a result of this audit hanging over their heads. So other inequities in the taxation system also place considerable burdens on small business people.

I turn to the prescribed payments system which now requires a contractor to deduct 15 per cent for tax. This 15 per cent is not only deducted from the wage component but also from the material component of a subcontractor. This may occur where there is a set legal contract to supply materials and labour and there is no separate contract. The separate account appears to be insufficient evidence of an individual contract as such. Thus, there are problems with the Taxation Office in the nature of the contract. The effect of all this is that the supplier of the goods loses 15 per cent, not only of the cost of the labour he provides but also of the cost of the materials he provides. In addition, he is also caught with provisional tax bills as well as the prescribed payments tax.

In the area of prescribed payments, assessments are being issued in certain circumstances which do not have a full legislative authority. I refer to situations where the taxpayer is in receipt of small salary income, from which instalment taxes have been deducted, in addition to prescribed payments. This is a situation where the Taxation Office is working ahead of the legislative requirements. I believe this is fairly serious. Far more serious is the fact that the Taxation Office has adopted the tactic of deducting provisional tax instalments from refunds that are due to the taxpayer even before the due payment date. Again, that is not right; it is quite wrong. What is needed is a thorough examination of this whole field of taxation legislation with a view to streamlining and consolidating the law rather than accepting the current practice of tacking on unsatisfactory amendments, as the Government is trying to do in the Bill before the Parliament today.

The administration of the tax law has now become so cumbersome and the Australian Taxation Office resources are so stretched that the system is near to collapse. I am not indicting the Taxation Office because it has some very dedicated officers. I am concerned about the intolerable position in which the Government has placed the Australian Taxation Office in making it a vehicle for its own propaganda and stretching its resources to such an extent that the Office is near to collapse. Let us look at this so-called taxation reform that we have before us. Just look at all the new imposts-fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, company dividend imputation, quarterly provisional tax. It all leads to the creation of chaos and intolerable backlogs because the Australian Taxation Office has difficulty in administering the law. There are also difficulties with the administration of returns caused by this complex legislation the Government is putting through. I am not blaming the Australian Taxation Office because it has been put in a intolerable position. We have to acknowledge as an Opposition-it is our responsibility to point it out-that there are major difficulties with the processing of returns, largely because of the strain on departmental resources.

Let me describe some of the problems. Final notices are being sent out after assessments have been paid. Assessments are also being sent out for amounts which are not yet due for payment. Refunds are being held to be offset against future instalment fees. The problem is that the Taxation Office needs a new computer. Its computers are incapable of handling the myriad of changes. But the consequences fall on the ordinary taxpayer. The explanation that all these problems are the fault of the computer is not good enough. The problems must be sheeted home to the Australian Labor Party. It has failed to provide the necessary resources. I acknowledge that the Taxation Office is re-equipping its computer system. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which I am Vice-Chairman, is assisting in this process in such a way as to make sure that the rights of ordinary individuals are not sat upon. Difficulties arise in regard to the location of suitable computer personnel. Surely the Government has to acknowledge this difficulty rather than just trampling on people's rights.

We are now beginning to feel the burden of this Government's haste to implement its so-called tax reform-tax reform which is biting deeper and deeper into ordinary people's pockets. Hasty decisions have been taken without due regard to their final consequences. The haphazard drafting of legislation has meant that time and again legislation has had to be reintroduced into this place to get it right. In December last year over 60 pages of amendments to fringe benefits tax legislation were passed by this Parliament simply to get right what the Government had earlier got wrong. In that month also a Bill was passed to remedy technical and drafting defects in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act which had been in the Senate only a few weeks before. Why the amendments were not made before the legislation was passed by both Houses is unexplainable.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many pages in the tax Act?
—There are 1,500 pages of legislation and over 2,500 rulings. I can put it down only to the haphazard approach this Government has taken towards taxation legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the decision to reverse the negative gearing measure, which followed its disastrous impact on housing, particularly in New South Wales. It is interesting to note that the 1987 decision to increase company taxation is now under review-another acknowledgment by the Government that it got it wrong in the past. These changes are welcome. However, they would have been unnecessary if the Government had got it right in the first place. The Government was warned by the Opposition and by the ordinary man in the street, but it would not listen. It has deaf ears. That is the price this Government has to pay for its so-called taxation reforms.

One of the objects of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 is to remedy taxation of lump sum superannuation. The changes to consolidate the tax concessions available to someone who has benefited from a deceased person's superannuation entitlements are reasonable and, naturally, will be supported by the coalition. We support these amendments because they are an attempt to get the situation right, but we do so with an amendment, reminding the Government of its responsibilities to the electorate. In the near future there are to be even more changes. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has assured us that any changes in taxation relating to superannuation funds and benefits will not be retrospective. That is a great promise, a great undertaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —You voted for retrospectivity in 1982. Come on, come clean.

—Not in relation to superannuation. The honourable senator knows that it was an entirely different thing. That is how hypocritical Senator Ray is-he tries to put the whole matter out of context. He tries to confuse this area of taxation and muddy the water so the ordinary person out there believes that there is some confusion. If there is any confusion, any misunderstanding, it comes from the Australian Labor Party because its members are hypocrites of the first order. The Treasurer said the other day that it is reprehensible to talk about extending consumption taxes. But what is the Government's record in sales tax, which is a consumption tax? It has extended it sinisterly. It is getting more money from this form of consumption tax and it is going to extend it to an even greater range of goods. Yet it will piously say, `We are not doing anything about a consumption tax' when all the time it will be moving in the direction of getting more and more money from indirect taxation, it is using the consumption tax lie to get more money from sales tax. It is on the Government's secret agenda. Let its members get up and deny that the Government is not going to extend it further, and to services as well.

SPEECH.PARA: What has this Government done in relation to petrol excise indexation since it came to office? The ordinary motorist knows full well that this Government has taken more from the petrol pumps than any previous government. It is responsible for increasing the price of petrol through its indirect system of taxation, quarterly indexation and so on. So let us not hear pious statements from the Government that it is against forms of indirect taxation, that it is against consumption taxes. It is using the vehicle that already exists-the sales tax legislation-to get more and more money. Government members should not be the hypocrites that they are. They really have soiled linen in the consumption tax area.

There are to be even more changes. There is no justification for taxing superannuation funds or benefits to finance cuts in ordinary company taxation rates. The benefits of superannuation funds flow primarily to individuals, and they should remain with individuals and not be transferred to the corporate sector. It is nothing short of immoral that the Government has collected $1.2 billion in taxation over and above the original Budget estimate. It deliberately understated its figures when it put the original fringe benefits legislation through. The Government is now contemplating taxing retirement benefits to fund reductions in the company tax rate.

Despite Treasurer Keating's claim back in September 1985 in his speech on the reform of the taxation system that `the Government's tax reform exercise is completed', we have continued to see legislative change after legislative change, month after month, year after year. How much longer will the Australian people be hoodwinked by statements such as the Treasurer's statement on tax reform? All the time the tax system is becoming more complex and the Treasurer is taking more and more money, both by direct and by indirect methods. It is time that Australia woke up. It is time that we had a simplified taxation law. It is time that the Government started putting money back into the pockets of ordinary Australians. The Labor Party must come clean.

With the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) we are faced with another element of retrospectivity. Whilst the changes in the rules relating to roll-over annuities are on the surface quite acceptable, they are yet another example of the Treasurer's penchant for legislation by Press release and an indication of the Government's contempt for the power of the ordinary parliamentary processes. We have seen plenty of examples of that. The facts are that many people do not have access to the original Press statement so that they have to go running to their tax accountants to get details of this complex area of tax legislation. Their plight is merely brushed aside by the Treasurer. But he is not alone in his behaviour.

On the other hand, if the taxpayer puts a foot wrong, albeit quite innocently, heavy penalties fall upon him. We seem to have moved to a situation where the ordinary person of Australia is guilty until proven innocent in regard to taxation law. I recently became acquainted with a case involving a 78-year-old man who suddenly got a tax bill which was quite out of line and character with his income. A mistake had been made as a result of the keying in of certain figures. He wrote to the Australian Taxation Office and objected. Instead of receiving an apology, he was sent a letter saying that if he did not pay the specified amount of money, which he did not have and which was about 10 times his true assessment, he would be subject to a harsh range of penalties. This was cold comfort for a 78-year-old gentleman with a heart problem who had never been subject to a traffic fine in his life. I must say that to the credit of the Taxation Office it speedily rectified the situation when I brought this matter to its attention. But just think of the hundreds of thousands of people who find themselves in the position of having to pay a tax because of an error for which they are not responsible but is a result of a keying error made by someone else. Our tax laws are in a shambles and the Labor Party has to take responsibility for this.

I would have liked to have spoken on a number of problems surrounding changes proposed by the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill. Unfortunately, my time has almost expired. The Government must move away from tinkering at the edges with the corporate tax review and make clear its intention to reduce significantly all tax rates in Australia to put more money back into the pockets of ordinary Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Opposition speakers, particularly Senator Watson, who has just resumed his seat. The Senate is examining yet another package of Government tax legislation. It seems impossible for one parliamentary session to pass without the Government fiddling with the tax structure which it has already imposed upon Australians. As Senator Watson said, we now have a tax Act of something like 2,000 pages.
—One thousand five hundred and 2,500 rulings.

—I thank Senator Watson-a tax Act of 1,500 pages and 2,500 rulings. Under this Government, printing the tax law is probably the biggest growth industry in Australia. Senator Short has, quite properly, moved an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987-this latest piece of tax law to be introduced by this Government. The amendment, which I strongly support, states:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living''.

That amendment sums up precisely the sorts of problems that this Government has imposed upon the Australian people through its booming tax laws, through its booming tax collections and through its imposition on ordinary Australian families of an intolerable tax bill.

Unfortunately, Senator Short's amendment understates the seriousness of the problem. Senator Short, as an honourable man, has taken the Government's word for it when he talks about how much more tax will be collected this year. In fact, we now know that Senator Short's amendment massively understates the amount of tax rip-off this year. This can be established clearly by looking at the latest release from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) which reveals that tax collections this year are far ahead of the Budget forecast. It reveals that the Government was pulling our legs when it said in the Budget that taxes would rise only by a modest amount and that, as a result, we would find that taxes as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) would fall from last year's record level. All of that is now absolute bunkum.

The statement released late last month by the Minister for Finance, which I might say got very little Press coverage, reveals that tax revenue for the month of February was 13.4 per cent higher than in February last year and that brings total revenue for the first eight months of 1987-88 to $46.6 billion. That amount is 13.4 per cent higher than for the corresponding months of the previous year. Tax revenue increased by 14.5 per cent. These outcomes are far higher than the Budget forecast that income tax would rise by something like 9.2 per cent this year. Instead, so far it is up 14.5 per cent. If you like, this is another broken promise.

As Senator Watson said, there is no doubt that this Government has a hidden agenda of secret tax rises which it is not prepared to face up to honestly in its Budgets but with which it hits the consumer and the taxpayer in a way that is supposed not to be noticed. So the statement in Senator Short's amendment that tax will equal 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product is, of course, not so. Tax collections will at least exceed last year's record taxes. Last year 24.8 per cent, or just under one-quarter of gross domestic product in this country, went in taxes. That record level will be exceeded this year. The Australian Labor Party has managed to have record levels of tax collections every year. It is sneakily doing so again this year, although it proudly said that it would not. As I said, this is part of the Hawke Government's secret agenda of belting the ordinary people of Australia with the highest tax bill that they have ever had in their lives, not only in money terms but also as a proportion of their incomes, as a proportion of the domestic product of this nation.

What are the facts as we now see them? As I have said, the Government's trilogy of promises to reduce the tax burden has clearly been broken over and over again. Promises made at the last election have been broken again. The commitment that was made in the last Budget has been broken again. Of course, we are now hearing the greatest hypocrisy that is possible from any government in the discussion about consumption tax.

So far I have spoken only about income tax and how the Government has sneakily increased the income tax burden. Everyone is used to the situation where income tax seems to go up sneakily all the time because inflation pushes taxpayers into a higher tax bracket. Suddenly people find that their pay rise results in a far greater tax rise. This Government, in particular, quite enjoys inflation which increases its tax revenue and helps to solve some of its problems.

We keep hearing that the Government has been terribly clever in cutting the Budget deficit. Let us recognise this: it is not the Government that has cut the Budget deficit; it is the taxpayers of Australia who have done so. After one takes account of inflation, there has still been a 13 per cent real rise in government spending under this Government. In other words, despite all of the rhetoric about cuts, under this Government government spending has gone up by something like 13 per cent. This means, of course, that the poor old taxpayer not only has had to pay for this increased spending in increased taxes, but also he has had to pay for cutting the deficit. In other words the Government, instead of doing the right thing and cutting the deficit as a responsible government would by cutting its own spending, has belted the taxpayer over and over again. There has been something like a 25 per cent real increase in tax collections-an intolerable burden on the Australian people.

Let me get back to the Government's hypocrisy about consumption taxes because it is there that the most insidious, the most secret, tax rip-off has taken place. As I have said, we all know and expect, particularly under this Government, that if we get a pay rise we get pushed into a higher tax bracket and, therefore, the Government's tax collections go up. As the Niemeyer statement said, that so far this year tax revenue is up about 14 1/2 per cent as against last year. I remind the Senate that the Government says that inflation will go up by only 6 per cent this year. Taxes are going up at more than double the inflation rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget estimate was only 8 per cent.

—As Senator Messner says, the Budget estimate was only about 8 per cent. The Government has clearly set out on a course of understating what the tax effect of its Budget will be and is secretly belting Australian taxpayers in a dishonest and dishonourable way. How dishonest and dishonourable is it on consumption tax? The way in which the Government's Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) talk, one would think that there was no such thing as a consumption tax in Australia now. Let me tell the Senate that consumption taxes already exist, as everyone knows, and that they are Australia's fastest growing taxes under the Hawke Government. So far this financial year, revenue from sales tax-sales tax is the biggest of the consumption taxes that have spread throughout Australia-has risen by 18 per cent, which is three times as fast as the inflation rate. The consumption tax rise, through the sales tax, has been faster than for all the other booming taxes under the Hawke Government.
—That takes some doing.

—As Senator Shorts says, it takes some doing to outpace the booming rise in income tax, for example. Income tax has gone up by 14.5 per cent. Sales tax-the consumption tax which the government pretends it does not have-has gone up by 18 per cent. There is no doubt that a little of that 18 per cent rise is due to the fact that that consumption tax has been extended to some government instrumentalities. But who ends up paying the consumption tax that government instrumentalities pay? Of course it is the people of Australia.
—The average weekly earner.

—The average weekly earner. That burden is certainly on the Australian people. What hypocrisy it is when not only is this Government pretending that it does not have a consumption tax but that tax is increasing at an even faster rate than the rip-off that all Australians are paying through their hip pocket in income tax.
—A lot of it is indexed too.
—As Senator Short says, many of those increases are indexed, so they happen automatically. As every beer drinker knows--
—It creeps up.

—Senator Patterson makes the appropriate point that the tax keeps creeping up. This style of government has meant that this 18 per cent sales tax rise is about 50 per cent higher than forecast by this Government in its Budget. In the Budget the forecast was 12 per cent. It is now running at about 18 per cent-a 50 per cent difference. It takes a lot of effort to make a 50 per cent mistake in a Budget forecast. The Government is half wrong. We on this side of the House wonder whether that mistake was not terribly convenient and whether it did not dress up the fact that this Government was setting out on a secret agenda of increasing consumption taxes while it was protesting that it did not have any. Sales tax, a consumption tax, will now total about $7.5 billion, whereas the Budget said that it would be only $6.3 billion. The honesty of this Government is being exposed by the figures of its own Minister for Finance.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the disgraceful performance in the current year, sales tax-sales tax is the biggest consumption tax among the many this Government has-has more than doubled, largely by stealth. It has gone from $3.5 billion in the last year of the Fraser Government to $7.5 billion this year. It has gone up by $4 billion-more than doubled. In fact, it represents a 110 per cent increase in the consumption tax which this Government says it does not have and is opposed to. This 110 per cent boom in sales tax is almost three times higher than the inflation rate during that period, which was about 39 per cent. The Government cannot say that that increase is due to inflation only; it has increased three times faster than the inflation rate.

No wonder many unions take the view that, if it is good enough for the Government to increase its income at a rate faster than that of inflation, why should some trade unionists not seek to try to maintain their income with the inflation rate? If the Government is genuine and honest in its approach to unions asking them to impose restraint, why has it not imposed the same sort of restraint on its own rip-off of the people? As I have said, under this Government, consumption taxes have risen three times as fast as inflation. In that time, wages, salaries and supplements have gone up by about 50 per cent as against the consumption tax rise of 110 per cent. The rise in this sales tax rip-off is more than double the rise in wages.

If one looks at the official statistics on the level of consumption in Australia, one will find that private sector consumption spending rose by about 60 per cent. So sales tax has risen by almost double the level of consumption. Is that not extraordinary? How can consumption taxes rise at almost twice the level of consumption? The answer is simple. It is because this Government has a secret agenda of ripping off Australian consumers with a sales tax while pretending that it is totally opposed to consumption taxes and that it does not have them. This is the most arrant and arrogant hypocrisy of which any Government could be accused.

While the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, expresses synthetic horror at any proposal to introduce a consumption tax, his Government has hit Australians with the highest level of sales tax-of course, sales tax is the ultimate in consumption taxes-in our history. In the Fraser days, sales tax made up only between 6 and 7 per cent of the total tax burden. Now, under the Hawke Government, instead of 6 or 7 per cent, it is about 10 per cent of the total tax burden, having risen at a far faster rate than all of the Hawke Government's other booming taxes.

Sales tax is only one of the very wide range of consumption taxes which Australians have to pay. Excise hits beer drinkers and motorists. Anyone who fills up his car with petrol recognises that the greatest proportion of the price of a litre of petrol goes in tax to the Government. In addition, there are import duties and tariffs. Recently I noted that a report suggested that the level of import duties and tariffs in Australia equals another $7 1/2 billion in a secret tax on Australian consumers. However, I have not included that in my concern about that 110 per cent increase in sales tax. So we have import duties and sales taxes hitting the buyers of cars, refrigerators and televisions, adding in these particular instances something like 30 per cent or more to their cost. This Government does not agree with consumption taxes; it says they do not exist. Yet it makes these extraordinary secret additions to revenue by way of these consumption taxes.

At the same time as this secret consumption tax rip-off has been taking place, income tax has also gone up. Under the Fraser Government income tax totalled about $28 billion. Under this Government it is now about $50 billion. This lifts the overall tax bill under the Hawke Government by something like $30 billion, to well over $72 billion. This income tax increase as well as the Government's indirect taxation, including its consumption tax, all taken together have meant a far faster rise in taxation than the rises in either inflation or wages. It represents a real increase in the total tax burden, after we take inflation into account, of about 25 per cent. As I said earlier, taxpayers are called on not only to pay for the Hawke Government's 13 per cent rise in real spending but also to carry the entire burden of reducing its deficit from the Hawke Government peak in 1984 of $8 billion. In passing, the last Fraser Government deficit was about $4 1/2 billion. The taxpayers have to pay for this 1984 Hawke Government $8 billion deficit as well as paying, on top of that, for a 13 per cent real rise in government spending.

Even worse than that, this secret rip-off sales tax or consumption tax is grossly unfair. A consumption tax is imposed on food, despite the absolutely nonsensical answer of the Minister for Finance to a question here the other day. His Government happily imposes sales taxes on food. Not even Senator Walsh can pretend that orange juice is not a food. I know it would very seldom pass his lips-other beverages seem to, but certainly not orange juice. Orange juice is clearly a food, yet this Government has imposed a consumption tax on it. We do not hear the Government admitting that; we do not hear Government senators even trying to talk about it. It does not exist as far as they are concerned. There is simply a mental block because of the basic dishonesty of this crooked Government, which has introduced a tax-a tax which did not exist under the previous Government on foods such as ice-cream. Is this Government saying that-that ice-cream is not a food? Try telling that to the parents of the millions of Australian children who now regard ice-cream, quite properly, as part of their basic diet. Kid's iceblocks and snack foods have all been hit with a consumption tax by this Government.

This Government apparently thinks it is fair to introduce such a tax. It does not speak about this situation; it pretends it does not exist and has said nothing about getting rid of it. While introducing taxes on foods like orange juice, ice-cream, snack foods and kids iceblocks, it has no consumption tax whatsoever on luxury items like $1,000 ball gowns. This Government has no consumption tax whatsoever on pornographic magazines. Perhaps this Government has as a priority putting taxes on food but not on pornographic magazines. I wonder whether taxes on other items, such as the boots people wear while playing polo, are sacrosanct while of course orange juice gets taxed? Maybe Mr Hawke's friends prefer to play polo than drink orange juice.

Everyone knows that the income tax rip-off keeps on sneaking up, but I think very few Australians are aware of Mr Hawke's huge hidden rises in consumption taxes-hidden rises introduced by a Government that has pledged itself not to introduce any consumption tax. It is intriguing that last week this Government even boasted that it had managed to raise more in consumption taxes, more in indirect taxes, than it would have raised had its broadly based indirect tax proposal of 1985 been implemented. There was a little item in the Australian Financial Review this week in which the Government effectively boasted about the fact that it had got in through the back door what it decided it should not try to get in through the front door. The great Keating indirect tax plan of 1985 was sabotaged by the Prime Minister in a dirty deal done in a motel room in Canberra. We now see that that proposal would have raised less money than this Government has now managed to sneak in through the back door as a result of its 110 per cent increase in consumption taxes.

I remind the Senate once again: this is a Government which says it does not have consumption taxes. It is a Government which said after the Taxation Summit of 1985 that it would not change the tax system to `introduce' a consumption tax. It did not have to introduce it; it could see that it could make even more money, it could rip even more out of the Australian people, by not introducing the consumption tax because all it had to do was, I think the expression is, remove anomalies and make adjustments. That is the way it has hidden, that is the way it has deceived the Australian people and got away with, these massive increases in consumption taxes-a 110 per cent rise in the period it has been in government.

So Labor has done by stealth what it was not prepared to do honestly in regard to consumption taxes. Certainly in my view and the view of many, this whole system clearly needs reforming so that this secret spread of consumption taxes is brought to an end. My own view, of course, is that there should be an honest and fair system of consumption taxes which would end this taxation by deceit that we have had under this Hawke Government. Naturally any reform of this dishonest system should be part of a genuine reduction in this massive total tax burden we face under the Hawke Government.

The major contribution the Hawke Government has made to the discussion of tax is to increase it to record levels while at the same time pretending that it has been showing restraint and cutting taxes. We know from the figures that what the Government has had to say about its role in reducing taxes is a total lie. Taxes are at record levels, not only in relation to everyone's pay packet but also as a proportion of this nation's gross domestic product. The share of this nation's wealth that is being ripped off by this Government is now higher than ever in our post-war history. Yet this is a government which pretends that it will show restraint and that people will be better off under it.

There are so many quotations that one can take from Mr Hawke which show either that he was recklessly indifferent to the truth and had no intention of keeping the promises or that his level of incompetence was so great that he has now, after the event, been proved totally wrong. Let us look at some of the statements by Mr Hawke, who misled the Australian people about the sort of tax future which faced them under a Labor government. I exclude from the present discussion the absolutely dishonest nonsense of recent days when Mr Hawke has said that the Australian Labor Party does not support a consumption tax. As I said, it is the fastest growing tax under the Labor Government. Let us go back to Mr Hawke's address to the National Press Club in 1984. He said:
In our next three year term of government the overall level of taxation will not increase as a proportion of gross domestic product.

That was a lie. There is no way that man could possibly have achieved that objective, and he did not. Over that period tax as a proportion of gross domestic product went up considerably. We have had the introduction of more and more taxes. Even worse, we have had the sneaky and dishonest introduction of a massive increase in consumption taxes in this country, hypocritically backed up by the pretence that this Government is opposed to them. What this nation desperately needs is an immense cut in the overall tax burden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow my colleagues Senator Michael Baume and Senator Watson in giving support to Senator Short's amendment, which clearly points out the burden imposed by this Government upon the real contributors to Australia, the working man and woman, the farmer and the small business person. That amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add `, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living'.

I give my full support to that amendment. This Government and honourable senators opposite must realise that any change to the Income Tax Assessment Act-we have No. 5 in front of us-will have strong repercussions throughout society. It will have a resounding effect upon ordinary Australians, the working man and woman, the small businessman and the farmer. We are being told today that we have before us a mere technical adjustment to fix up unintended consequences. This Government should realise, and it probably has realised, that its constituents believe that the main issue today is the burden of tax upon Australians. They are fed up with paying their hard-earned money to a government with absolutely no direction whatsoever and with no beg your pardons.

While the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) gives some relief from the capital gains tax to resident unit trusts-and that is something not to be opposed-the question must be asked: Why has relief from capital gains tax not been given to small business, to owner operators, to the one or two person or, indeed, family, operation? Families often better themselves by selling one business and moving on to another. More often than not, this betterment or increase in the value of their business is in the form of goodwill. Goodwill in essence is the main part of the wealth of any owner operator. It is an asset that all Australians can buy into. It is basically defined as talent, hard work and entrepreneurship. That is the formula for goodwill. It gives every Australian the opportunity to share in this nation's resources. Small business is at the cutting edge of competition. It is the best vehicle for new entrepreneurial talents and inventions. At the heart of the wealth of any small business operation is goodwill.

It should be remembered that small businesses starting up are not asset rich-they often lease their premises-but they are talent rich. So in essence the capital gains tax is a tax on talent. It prevents new businesses starting up, particularly in the business sector, protecting the already well-established, the asset rich. No wonder this Government is setting up committees to look into the Trade Practices Act because of the now too-late concern about unhealthy moves towards monopolies or market domination by a few firms. We have heard recently the announcement of a small business inquiry to look into certain aspects of small business. One of its terms of reference, No. 3, is:
The ultimate extent of policies on small business compared with larger business.

The Government has suddenly woken up, albeit too late, that there is a difference between small and large business, that certain policies have to be tailored differently for small business. But it is too late, because the business tax review that this Government is undertaking at the moment will probably be finalised before this committee even sits. Before the small business inquiry even sits the Government will have already laid down its new tax requirements for corporate Australia. So it is all too late. The agenda for the past five years has been centred on big business with no concern at all for small business. That is why we have this new market concentration-the mergers, the takeovers and the monopolistic practices in the marketplace. Unless we unleash the ability of one person, the owner-operator, who begins asset poor but talent rich, unless we give him or her a chance to create wealth through the goodwill of a business-unless we rekindle that spirit-and unless governments allow the great potential of all Australians to be unleashed, we can expect no more than the development of a corporate state led by big government, big corporations and big unions which will at best preside over a very selective recovery for this nation.

We have had the Button steel plan and we have had the Button car plan. What about the Button small business plan? Does Senator Button not realise that we have 800,000 businesses employing 2.3 million people? The great disappointment in this Government's long awaited business tax review is that it does not target small business. Rather, all we have heard from the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is that the Government intends to flatten the playing field in this business tax review. It is neither here nor there that it intends to flatten the playing field because it has already flattened the main players, the 800,000 small businesses that employ 2.3 million people. The Government can use that in vogue term-flatten the playing field-but it is a waste of time if it does not concentrate on the different needs of small business.

Will this business tax review take into account the special requirements of small business in the area of sales tax burdens? I doubt it. What is likely, as has been reported, is that new rules governing the administration of sales tax will be introduced that will effectively increase sales tax by about 10 per cent on a much wider range of goods than is already affected. One outstanding feature of the sales tax method of collection that discriminates against small businesses and affects their cash flows, particularly those of new businesses, is the requirement for small businesses to pay the sales tax for the preceding month's sales on the twenty-first day of the month. The Small Business Council, which operates under Senator Button's own Department, has stated:
In fact, it is likely that less than 50% of the debts would have been received by this date.

So they are paying out tax before they get money in. The solution recommended by the Small Business Council is that the date for payment of sales tax should be extended by 30 days to the twenty-first day of the second month following those credit sales. That means that the sales tax would not be paid by businesses until they get the money in. That is fair. That is what small businesses need to improve their cash flow. The history of the Hawke Government has not been one of cooperation with the business sector. Big business has been high on the agenda, and I instance the Business Council of Australia. From the start of the Hawke Government's term five years ago the agenda of both Hawke and groups of big business has been anti-small and medium business. Their agenda has included the centralisation of wage fixing policies, a greater concentration of unions, and proposals to centralise company law-making in Canberra.

In relation to the centralised wage fixing system in this country-better known as the industrial relations club-it should be pointed out that for years industrial relations in this country were allowed to run amuck. No attempt was made to check the misuse of power and irresponsibility of the union bosses. It was peace at any price. It took small business operators to show courage and fight back against absurd work practices. I particularly refer to the Dollar Sweets case in Victoria, which was a landmark in industrial relations in this nation.

Every small business group and every chamber of commerce condemns the manifesto of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Australia Reconstructed, as they condemn the proposal to centralise the national companies code in Canberra. The intent of this Government is quite clear; it wants to centralise company law. This is particularly evident if we take the word of the honourable member for Barton, Mr Punch. He describes the transfer of power over company legislation from the States to the Federal Government as a move towards a `deregulated corporate environment'. That is a fancy term for centralised power in Canberra at the expense of the States and of our federal system. That may not be a revelation given the platform of the Australian Labor Party, but it is a policy and a philosophy that is directly pitched against small business.

Also included in the main Bill before us is an amendment to tax superannuation payments, upon the death of a superannuation contributor, to the deceased contributor's non-dependent adult children. This amendment, it is claimed, is necessary on the grounds of equity, but if equity is an issue in the taxation treatment of superannuation, attention must focus on the position of the self-employed-a vital part of small business. The self-employed, as well as the non-sponsored employees, are grossly discriminated against under the current arrangements. The larger companies may claim up to the full maximum superannuation benefit allowed by the Australian Taxation Office. For employees at the prime of their working life, for example, this may be up to $5,000 per annum. The company which employs them may claim that full amount as a tax deduction. On the other hand, a self-employed small business person, earning over his working life a similar amount, may claim only up to $1,500 as a tax deduction. That is $1,500 for the self-employed compared to $5,000 for a company. This represents clear discrimination against self-employed small businessmen.

The issue of superannuation is also vitally related to the greatest single economic problem facing Australia today-our $110 billion foreign debt. If Australia's foreign debt is to be tackled, we have to increase the savings of this nation. The latest Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) paper, Australia's Medium Term Growth Potential, holds some hope that Australia's foreign debt may level out by the 1990s. This is primarily based on two very important assumptions: firstly, that there is no change in Australia's terms of trade over the next few years-that is utterly unrealistic; secondly, and directly relevant to the taxation of superannuation with which the Bill before us is concerned, that domestic savings will increase and consumption will decrease by 2.5 per cent by 1992. It is clear that the Government is considering increasing tax on superannuation. So it is at loggerheads in meeting the great challenge of reducing our foreign debt. It will be a direct disincentive for Australians to save for their retirement. An increased tax on superannuation may push many financially independent people into the welfare state. That is the last thing Australia needs today. The Government is showing itself to be incapable of delivering the taxation reform that the populace demands-real tax reform that reduces the overall tax burden. We do not want any new taxes; we want a reduction in existing taxes.

The Government's tax policy, like the two Bills before us, is at best only an exercise in shifting the deck chairs. It is behaving like a stunned rabbit at the moment after its quite stunning electoral defeats. It is almost frozen with inaction. It is not willing to tackle Australia's greatest problem-foreign debt. In fact, we do not hear members of the Government talking about it much these days. Look at the way the Government has taxed the hopes and dreams of Australians in small business, the working man and woman and the farmer, through its capital gains tax, its superannuation tax. It has never got down to tackling Australia's foreign debt. Government members need a good 20 years in opposition so they can learn how to be Australians again. The real contributors to Australia's growth have been forgotten. They are now expressing frustration and distaste for the politics of this Government. This can best be illustrated by a letter received by the Ballarat Courier recently. I will not name its author, but obviously he is from the heartland of a Labor constituency. He sums up that existing frustration, particularly in the area of taxation. I will quote the greater part of the letter:
I am 37 years of age, born to a labourer who indoctrinated me that under Labor I would lead a better life. Therefore, for 18 years as a voter I have always voted Labour. What a great mistake!
Quite correct. The letter goes on:
In 1969 as a single person I earned $40 a week and paid $4 a week tax. The government then took one-tenth of my weekly earnings in tax.
Today under a Labor Government I earn $500 per week and pay $120 per week in tax, thus more than one-fifth goes to the tax man.

I am now married with two children but we are a single income family. In 1973 I borrowed $10,000 to build our own home. The State Bank charged me 6.75 per cent interest so my quarterly repayments were $174, now in 1988 I have paid back $14,000 yet I still owe $8,000 on my principal. My quarterly repayments are $316 and the interest rate has risen to 13.75 per cent.

And so he goes on. He gives a clear warning to the honourable member for Ballarat from the Labor Party, Mr Mildren, that the Labor Party has lost its bearings. All he can say is that it should watch out at the next federal election. That is a fair warning which is already coming through the ballot box. It seems to me that if Labor does not get into a hands-on situation very quickly, that message will wipe it out of this Parliament completely. One would think at least the newest member of the Senate, Senator McMullan, would bring that fresh approach into the Senate straight from the electorate and would be able to convince his colleagues that there is a feeling out there that the Labor Party has got to tackle the real and serious issues. One would think that Senator McMullan could convince his colleagues of this. But that is not so. Senator McMullan has come from the bear pit, from the party machine itself, and he is about as unrealistic as the others. There is fair evidence of that from his letter to the Australian that the Government's record on economics is just fine. He said `We have produced falling unemployment, falling interest rates, falling inflation, a falling balance of payments and a balanced Budget'. He is not willing to face reality either-falling from very high levels that Labor created, but they are just not falling enough. It worries me that Senator McMullan is probably the last hope that we have that at least the senators in the Labor Party will realise just how much they are rubbing in to ordinary Australians, their erstwhile supporters. I think Senator McMullan should spend his time looking for a few of the old-time Labor parliamentarians who used the hands-on approach. It would not hurt him to check up on a few of the old Democratic Labor Party parliamentarians that have left. They were good hands-on people. We have only to look at their vote in Victoria, which doubled, and which no doubt came from the Labor heartland. Perhaps the Labor Party should consider looking for better candidates than it has at the moment.

I again give my full and strong support to the amendment moved by Senator Short. As I have said, it clearly outlines the burden placed upon the real contributors to this country, the working man and woman, the farmer and the small business person.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill, and I rise to support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Short to the motion for the second reading. A few years ago, because of an election throw-away line on talkback radio, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-who, incidentally, has become an embarrassment and a liability to his Party-promised to have a tax summit. The aim was presumably to make taxation more equitable and simpler. As everyone knows, it was an abject failure on both counts. From a simplicity point of view, it certainly encouraged a growth industry, and that industry was in the area of tax accounting, because the system has now become so complex that almost everyone must consult a tax accountant before submitting a tax return. It is beyond the knowledge of ordinary Australians, and even of most people in small business, to be able to get themselves around the mess that we have through our taxation laws.

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone in our society, particularly that foundation stone of Australian society, the battling family, is worse off than they have ever been in Australian history. There are some on the Labor benches who, because of vociferous statements made by loony groups, would argue about whether the family is the foundation stone of Australia; but in fact, it is. It is for this reason, which everyone knows except the out of touch Prime Minister and his equally out of touch Labor Government, that Labor has been rejected politically in South Australia, New South Wales and, very recently, in the seat of Groom in my State of Queensland. It should be remembered that the very hard core Labor primary vote in Groom that has, year in and year out, stuck to the Labor Party, for whatever reason, decreased by about 8 per cent.

People are fed up with the level of tax that they must pay and with the purchasing power of the few dollars that they have left after the Government has raided their pay packets. The only people who are not complaining are the few rich mates of the Prime Minister. Together with the leaders of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, they are the de facto government of Australia.

This callous Government, as pointed out recently by Mr Eric Risstrom in the Taxpayer, is politically cynical and `devoid of any caring for people or the economy'. I think even Senator Robert Ray would agree that Mr Risstrom will criticise either of the major political parties if he believes the taxpayer is being overburdened and taken to the cleaners. Out of a possible $27 a week pay rise, this Government will take $11 a week in tax. This is a great disincentive for, for instance, people working overtime. I think that anyone who gets around the electorates, whichever State he or she comes from, will realise that this is probably one of the greatest common complaints. What is the use of working a few hours overtime to increase the amount of money to come to the family when it will be raided by a rapacious government? A one-income family with two children now needs about $42 a week more to restore its real disposable income to the level it was when this discredited Prime Minister and this discredited Labor Party got into power in 1983. Tax paid by that family has increased by 30 per cent to $117 a week. This rip-off by the Government, coupled with an inflation rate which has increased the costs of goods and services, has made life for the average family unbearable and intolerable, as shown in recent election results. Surely that message must eventually sink in.

This Government has financially crippled middle and low income earners in Australia, the big, silent majority which has its say at election time-or those Sir Robert Menzies referred to as the forgotten people. The root of the problem, as everyone knows, is the size of government and, in particular, the growth in government programs. The Government now spends around 45 per cent of the national product compared with 30 per cent in 1968. Taxation on average earnings has risen from 11 per cent in 1958 to 24 per cent today. I believe it is worth quoting from the editorial of the 26 March edition of the Taxpayer, which reads in part:

. . . the out-of-touch people forget that Australia is made up of more than employees. Such a policy ignores many on fixed incomes, many who received their last tax cut in November, 1985. Facing such a four-year tax-cut drought is frightening for anyone caught in such a political web.

I've never urged revolt before, but perhaps I've never been so moved before by such blatant political manipulation. The time has come for a tax revolt. Write to the press and politicians, ring their offices, write to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, ring your local radio station-and yell!
Remember: In just four years, the CPI went up 35%, Canberra spending rose by 38%, with a 65% jump in taxation.
