—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to the spectacular revelations before the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, centred on prostitution and vice. Prior to the Fitzgerald inquiry, was any Minister alerted by a senior officer to the special need to investigate the incidence of vice and its links with organised crime and corruption? If so, what action has been taken in response?
—I am having difficulty in understanding. Does the honourable senator mean vice and organised crime in Queensland which was brought to the attention of a Federal Minister?

—By way of explanation, was any Minister alerted by a senior officer to the special need to investigate generally, throughout Australia, the incidence of vice and its links with organised crime and corruption?

—It is such a very general question. Of course the links between organised crime and the sorts of activities which have been revealed in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry are well known and have been the subject of consideration by governments-and indeed by this Parliament-over many years. No doubt Ministers and members of this chamber will have considered those links that have been pointed out by many authoritative voices over many years. That is one of the matters which led to the establishing of the National Crime Authority, after the reception of a report from the Senate committee. As I recall it, part of the terms of reference of the National Crime Authority as set out in the statutory charter point to that whole question of vice and its links with organised crime. There has always been a general awareness amongst Ministers, based on well-sourced information, of the sort of link to which the honourable senator is referring. I am sorry if I am being a bit obtuse but I cannot grasp the particularity of what the honourable senator is seeking.

—I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to an article in a recent edition of the Australian Financial Review suggesting that some firms are to issue unsolicited credit cards to consumers. In view of the already high level of consumer debt in Australia, can the Minister indicate whether the Government can take any steps to ensure that this method of providing easy credit does not continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devereux rightly refers to an article in the Australian Financial Review where it was mentioned that Country Road Clothing Pty Ltd was going to be issuing, unsolicitedly, credit and debit cards to its customers. This issue is a major concern of the Government at a time when the availability of easy credit seems to be on the rise. Our concern is reflected by the fact that next week we will be holding in Canberra, under the auspices of the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, a forum on consumer credit. The two problems the Government has with easy credit such as this are, first, that often interest rates are excessive and, secondly, there is often an inadequacy in credit rating assessment procedures. So the issue that Senator Devereux raises is of concern to us.

ANSWER.PARA: With particular reference to the instance mentioned in the Australian Financial Review relating to Country Road, the Trade Practices Commission has investigated the report and is satisfied that the retailer in this instance has no such intention as indicated in the article. So no further action needs to be taken with Country Road. However, it is worth while mentioning-and in response to Senator Devereux's question-that part V of the Trade Practices Act, and in particular section 63a of that Act, refers to and specifically prohibits the unsolicited distribution of credit and debit cards to prospective customers and any contravention of this section could result in criminal and civil liability. In short, the answer to Senator Devereux is yes, we have seen the article. In this instance, because of the intentions of Country Road not to issue customers with cards unsolicitedly, there is no contravention of the Trade Practices Act but if a corporation or individual were to issue cards in an unsolicited manner, that could very well be a breach of the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and concerns the announced changes to the Government's car plan. I note my own State of South Australia's critical dependence on the now strongly developed car manufacturing plants of Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd and General Motors-Holden's Ltd. Given that the car industry is currently producing about 100,000 units a year fewer than what is regarded as its traditional base of production, what is the Government going to do to help the industry recover that base, or does the Government expect production volumes to remain at current levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not expect production volumes to remain at current levels but everybody in this country is fully aware that two factors were operating in 1986 and 1987 in the car market which had a very depressing effect on that market. The first was the depreciation of the Australian dollar particularly against the yen and the fact that that increased the price of imported cars and imported componentry that went into locally manufactured cars. The second factor was that because of the current account problem which this country had, because we were borrowing more than we were earning, the Government introduced policies which restrained and suppressed wages. There has been a significant reduction in wages in the last few years. Those two factors, operating together, had a depressing effect on the car market.
—And the fringe benefits tax.
—The honourable senator always interjects about the fringe benefits tax. Certainly that had an effect on the market in 1986. I think the long term effect is marginal.

ANSWER.PARA: A motor vehicle, for those people who do their sums, is still a good fringe benefit compared with other things which were used in the past as fringe benefits. We had the same argument about the restaurant industry, that the abolishment of the entertainment concession was going to ruin the restaurant industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it put a lot out of business.

—Senator Newman interjects that some of them went out of business. I would hope so. Having had to dine at some restaurants I hope a lot of them went out of business-they were terrible. That is a factor in a dynamic market. The Opposition sees the world as some sort of static model where everything remains the same, where all the restaurateurs and car manufacturers remain in business forever.
—Stop heaping it up. We will all need four-wheel drive vehicles to drive over the nonsense you are going on with.

—That is the quality of interjections one hears from honourable senators opposite, including the Leader of the Opposition, who, to his disgrace, was wandering around the chamber talking to people before he made that silly interjection. He can do much better than that. By Opposition standards he is a very capable politician.

ANSWER.PARA: I say to Senator Teague that the industry derived some encouragement from the car market situation in February. I think that the changes made by the Government which were announced this week will help the car market. I do not expect any dramatic change in the next few months, but I think there will be an improvement. Senator Teague's question proceeded from his view of a static model of an industry. Next year, 30,000 built up cars will be exported from Australia. It is the first time that that has happened for many years. It means volume for the industry, employment for people working in the industry and dollars earned for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the macro-economic policies of your Government.

—Senator Lewis interjects because he does not like the answer that I am giving, so he tries to divert the topic to one which is totally different. I understand the technique, but it is pretty old and tired. I say to Senator Teague that I expect some improvement in the market. In so far as he asked the question as a South Australian senator, let me say that I am very confident about the medium and long term stability and success of the motor vehicle industry in South Australia-both the two companies that he mentioned and the component sector of the industry in South Australia-provided that it keeps at the task of improving its quality, its production techniques, and so on, which it must do.

—Is the Minister for Local Government aware of the concerns expressed by local government across Australia about rumoured reductions in the level of funding for local roads? Can the Minister advise what the Government intends in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the widespread concern by local governments about possible changes to road funding. I have been working very closely with my colleague in the other place, the Hon. Peter Morris, who has direct responsibility for the funding of local roads. Since early March I have visited a number of councils in four States-metropolitan and rural -and I am very well aware of their extreme concern that they may be overlooked in some way in regard to road funding issues. I have reassured them that this is certainly not the Government's intention and that everything possible will be done to maintain the appropriate levels of local government road funding within the constraints of Senator Walsh's plans in terms of the forthcoming economic statement and Budget. I have also spoken with New South Wales local government engineers. Of course, they are very concerned about the infrastructure needs of this country in terms of economic development.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not good enough to look at the road funding question purely in terms of local community needs, although, of course, that is of fundamental concern to many people. We must look at it in terms of the fundamental infrastructure needs of the country, export opportunities and the maintaining of our assets. Enormous amounts have gone into road funding over many years. Of course, the levels of funding must be maintained in terms of good assets management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all roads.

—I am sure that Senator Walsh does not disagree with me. I would like to take this opportunity, in responding to Senator Burns's question, to read from Life Has Never Been Easy, a report of the survey of women in rural Australia which was undertaken by the Office of the Status of Women in consultation with the Country Women's Association.
—How about tabling it.
—I am happy to table it. In regard to the importance of road funding issues, I quote from page 17 of the report:

ANSWER.PARA: Transport and communications are central to the quality of life in rural Australia . . . It is also supported by the survey findings, where 11.3 per cent of respondents indicated that long distances, public transport, road conditions and communications were their biggest problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not need a survey to tell you that.

—I inform Senator Vanstone that women were asked to indicate their personal preferences regarding government spending in rural areas, and that 69 per cent of respondents believed that roads should be a priority. I say to Senator Burns that obviously it is very important that we keep in mind the high priority that is placed on road funding issues generally in both rural areas, as I have indicated, and metropolitan areas. I am sorry that Senator Stone is not in the chamber at the moment. He represents a country party. I am not quite sure which country party Senator Stone may represent in the future, Mr President, because, as you are probably aware, the former Premier of Queensland has announced his intention to form a new party. I am sure that Senator Stone will welcome some of the views that have been expressed by rural women and will keep them well in mind when he is involved in targeting cutbacks, as proposed by Opposition policy.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that a serviceman of 28 years standing, when being interviewed recently by his superior officers, was advised that there was an entry on his file stating that he is a member of a subversive organisation, the HMAS Sydney and Vietnam Logistical Support Veterans Association? Is it true that the HMAS Sydney and Vietnam Logistical Support Veterans Association, which belongs to the kindred organisations of the Returned Services League, is classified by any Australian security organisation as subversive and, if so, why? Are any other ex-service organisations classified as subversive by any Australian security organisation and, if so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since this matter has been brought to my attention efforts have been made to establish the circumstances alleged by Senator McLean. The Minister for Defence is not aware of the incident. The Chief of the Defence Force and the Chiefs of Staff of Navy, Army and the Air Force have no knowledge of such an incident. Investigations to date have not provided any evidence that the statements were made. Naturally, of course, these investigations would be hampered by the fact that no essential detail has yet been provided. I can understand the reluctance to specify the particular case, but it does make it fairly hard to investigate. I assure the honourable senator that the Minister for Defence is anxious to pursue the substantive matters that he has raised. I would be happy to pass on any information that the honourable senator has to facilitate that inquiry.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the allegation that the HMAS Sydney and Vietnam Logistical Support Veterans Association is regarded as a subversive organisation, I point out that this Government has amended the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act to remove the definition of `subversion', and that such action would seem to me to run counter to the claims that lists of subversive organisations have been compiled and maintained. Certainly, as I am informed, no such list exists in the Defence Department or within the Australian Defence Force.

Finally, I have been assured that the aims and aspirations of the association referred to by Senator McLean are commendable and are pursued in an undisguised, forthright and tenacious manner. The Government respects the Association, as it does all the others that pursue veterans' interests. The final part of Senator McLean's question asks for a list of subversive organisations. I know of none. I know of none in the Defence Department, and I also believe there should be none there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question: Can the Minister undertake to advise the Senate regarding procedures by which this serviceman, without resigning, can determine whether such an entry exists on his service file?

—I will pursue that matter on, let us say, a confidential basis if the honourable senator gives me the information. I would imagine that in certain circumstances we could have that file made available to that individual. However, I think that is a matter we can proceed down the track with. I might just say that it would be very unfair to such a serviceman if there were such a file entry and if it in any way inhibited his career in the Services. I would take a very dim view of that. Maybe at some stage we can get to the honourable senator advice as to the serviceman's rights in pursuing that matter. If that does not get us down the track further we will look at other methods that we, in government, can take, rather than those that that serviceman can take, to facilitate that end.
—I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications: What are the Government's plans for Essendon Airport and, if the airport is to continue, on what basis will it be financed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to clarify this matter because it has been the subject of some public misunderstanding and concern. The situation is that the Federal Government will not seek the rezoning of residential land around Essendon Airport. We have never had any plans to do so and this remains firm policy. Nor does the Government intend to relax the current night curfew or expand the airport or the range of aircraft operations it supports. The view that has been taken by both the Federal and State governments-and this was agreed last year-was that Essendon Airport should remain open, as it does form an important component of Victoria's airport strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Airports Corporation, which has assumed control of Essendon, is of course looking to improve the airport's performance, but it will be seeking to do so through cost containment and by expanding non-aviation commercial development on the airport itself, not through promotion of expanded aircraft activity. The Corporation will make its own provision for funding of any development, as is provided for under the Federal Airports Corporation Act. The Essendon Airport role review study, which has been the subject of much recent public debate, has made a number of recommendations aimed at reducing the effects of aircraft operations on the Essendon community. These recommendations cover issues such as tightening the existing night curfew, excluding operations by larger aircraft, excluding some noisy aircraft which currently use Essendon and restricting the maintenance running of aircraft engines to minimise, again, noise pollution.

The Federal Airports Corporation will continue to liaise with local government and resident groups regarding Essendon's future. Because of Essendon's close physical relationship with Melbourne Airport at Tullamarine, the report of the role review has also been incorporated into the Melbourne Airport strategy process which is being conducted in conjunction with the Victorian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-a question which I had hoped to ask the Minister today. As the Minister would be aware, the committee investigating the World Heritage listing of the northern rainforest has arrived in Australia today. Will the Minister inform the Senate today of the itinerary of the committee that is investigating the World Heritage listings? What attempts will it be making to canvass local opinion in the region? What is the cost of the visit to Australia?

—This matter was first raised by Senator Boswell some time ago. Senator Richardson the other day very kindly induced a backbencher on this side to ask him a dorothy dixer in reply to which he then outlined very extensively what the itinerary was and all the local groups to be consulted. I do not remember all those details but they will be in the Hansard of either Wednesday or Thursday. I know it is easy to miss these things, but the Minister went into great detail as to where the committee was going and who it was seeing and convinced at least me that a wide cross-section of those people in north Queensland who have concerns in this area, from local governments to mill owners, to timber workers and the tourist people in Cairns-the whole spread of the community-would get exposure to the committee. I know initially there was some concern as to whether this committee would be squired around and given, if you like, the high road tour. No, it will get to see everything and everyone will have access to it so that all points of view can be put forward.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article by Michael Short in yesterday's Age newspaper which dismisses in one sentence the argument that a consumption tax is regressive by stating, `Adjustments in the social security system can easily compensate the poor'? Is it possible to easily compensate the poor through adjustments to the social security system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly not easy to compensate social security recipients if they are classified as the poor-and I suppose that is about as good a definition as any other-and certainly not easy to compensate social security recipients for any indirect tax which adds substantially to prices and the consumer price index. For example, option C which was being considered by the Government three years ago had within it a proposal to fully compensate pensioners and other social security recipients for the price increases which would be caused by the contemplated consumption tax. That would have cost well over $1 billion in 1986 prices. It would be considerably more than that today.

ANSWER.PARA: However, that does not tell the whole story. Any change to the taxation system which adds to the price level becomes a capital levy for people who are living on lump sum compensation or for any retiree who derives income from a fixed capital sum or who has been compensated in some way with a capital sum which is supposed to last a lifetime. Of course, included in that group is anybody who is, or is likely to become, a superannuation recipient. Any indirect tax which adds, let us say, 6 per cent to the price level is a de facto capital levy of 6 per cent on everybody who has had a superannuation lump sum payment, anybody who has had a compensation lump sum payment or, indeed, anybody who holds any assets in cash at all. It is a capital levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —A reduction in income tax is a capital gain.

—I am glad that Senator Chaney mentioned a reduction in income tax. John Elliott and his mates could get a reduction in income tax while they were guzzling their Vat 69 in the tax deductible box at Princes Park, gobbling their free lunch with their free tickets to the footie, while the people down there in the outer who were munching their pies and who paid for their tickets to the footie would get taxed on both. That is exactly why John Elliott wants the consumption tax. Income tax is not a major problem for social security recipients. Indeed, a large number of social security recipients pay no income tax at all. I think that that is the point of Senator Zakharov's question. An increase in indirect tax, a broadly based consumption tax, a VAT-not the Vat 69 that John Elliott and his mates guzzle up in that tax deductible box at Princes Park-or some other broad-based consumption tax, would impose higher prices on everybody, which obviously would seriously disadvantage social security recipients unless they were fully compensated for the increased prices. As I said, that would cost well over $1 billion for a tax of between 6 and 7 per cent. Such a tax also disadvantages people who are not social security recipients and who have received or are about to receive a lump sum, because it is in fact a capital levy.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy may be aware of a recent Sydney District Court ruling that resulted in two people, both of whom are involved in the commercial avicultural industry and who pleaded guilty to a charge of bird smuggling, being convicted without penalty and released on a small good behaviour bond. Given that the Act under which the two men were tried has penalties of some tens of thousands of dollars and given that bird smuggling is a most serious threat to Australia's disease free status, what comment does the Minister, who is responsible for quarantine, have on the matter? The Minister would also be aware that there has been some question of an appeal being lodged against the leniency of the penalty. Can the Minister advise whether an appeal has indeed been lodged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question invites me to comment on a decision handed down by a judge who heard a case and determined on the evidence before him a particular penalty. I must say that I do not think it is appropriate for me to do that. The second part of the question was whether I could say whether an appeal is to be lodged. That matter would be sub judice and it is not appropriate for me to deal with that.

ANSWER.PARA: In the generality, of course, the Government is concerned to guarantee the quarantine laws of the country. The Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service is extremely active in this regard. The costs to the country should our quarantine laws be breached could be quite horrendous, depending on what exotic diseases or pests were brought into the country by such a breach. I believe the Quarantine Service goes about its tasks as zealously as one would expect, given its responsibility. I do not think it is appropriate for me to express a view about a judge who has made a decision after he has heard the evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs hear the Australian Broadcasting Corporation news item this morning in which it was said that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) spent approximately $100,000 on its own consultation concerning the Government's proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC)? Does this not appear to be at odds with the explanation provided by the ADC in its documentation to Senate Estimates Committee E that increased expenditure on administrative costs for the financial year to date was `principally' due to expenditure incurred on additional Commission meetings called to discuss the Government's ATSIC proposal when the increase was in the order of $800,000? Can the Minister please provide details of the ADC's administrative expenditure for the 1986-87 financial year and the expenditure for 1987-88, both actual and planned? Can the Minister also provide details of expenditure by the ADC related in any way to the ATSIC?

—Honourable senators will be aware that some of these matters were canvassed in the Estimates committee at which I was actually the Minister at the table last night. I have not had a chance fully to check the Hansard of the hearing but I do recall that evidence was given by the Chairman and the General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission that they had spent in the order of $90,000-it was expressed in terms of one and two-thirds of a home-being the opportunity cost, on the consultation process. Exactly how that ties in with the Senate Estimates Committee booklet which indicates that the ADC was seeking some $800,000 in increased expenditure for administrative purposes and that, concerning that $800,000, principally the moneys were required to fund meetings called to discuss the Government's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal, is a little unclear. I will certainly take Senator Gietzelt's question back to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, and try to obtain the details sought by him.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that yesterday the Prime Minister confirmed that further tariff cuts were on the way? Is the Minister aware of the report in the Australian Financial Review of today that the `Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet last night agreed in principal to a ``tops down'' reduction in tariffs, which would phase in a single maximum tariff for most industries'? Is the Minister aware of reports in today's Daily Commercial News that `investment projects worth tens of millions of dollars of investment are being put on ice because the Federal Government refuses to end the massive speculation surrounding tariff reductions to industry prior to the May statement' and that `the ongoing speculation threatens to divert multi-million dollar projects away from Australian industry'? Is the Government really going to wait until 25 May or thereabouts before ending this speculation? Are the Prime Minister and the members of the Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet, which I presume includes the Minister, so naive and out of touch with commercial reality that they really believe that the commercial world can afford to wait another month before these decisions are announced?

—I am aware of the various reports to which Senator Lewis referred, including some comment by the Prime Minister and an article which appeared in today's Australian Financial Review. The other journal quoted was the Daily Commercial News, a paper which I assure Senator Lewis I read avidly. Let me first make this point: sure there is speculation and comment about possible tariff cuts in the 25 May statement.
—Being stirred by your Ministers.

—I understand the point Senator Lewis was trying to make. Sure there is speculation about that. I think it is important to distinguish between tariff cuts which are introduced precipitately and tariff cuts which might be made over a period. If tariff cuts are to be made precipitately I think it is very important that there should be no public speculation about it. If tariff cuts are to be made over a period I do not think it is a bad thing for industries to be addressing their minds to the issue, particularly the relevance of high tariffs in a floating exchange rate environment. I still think tariffs are very relevant but they are less relevant than they might have been in circumstances where there was a fixed exchange rate. Let me make this point: Senator Lewis quoted from the Daily Commercial News about millions of dollars of investment being postponed and people sitting on their hands and all that sort of stuff because of speculation in the newspapers. The most competitive sectors of Australian industry are not protected by tariffs at all. Is the aluminium industry sitting on its hands worrying about tariff reductions? It does not have any tariffs. Is the computer software industry sitting on its hands agonising about tariffs? It does not have any tariffs.
—They are more worried about tax.
—Of course they are more worried about tax. It might not be a bad idea to speculate about tax too.
—Some of them are more worried about your partnership with Ray.

—Senator Lewis is what used to be called at the time of the Vietnam war a `threat expert'. He luxuriates in anxiety, not only having it himself but also engendering it in other people. Sure, there are sectors of Australian industry which might be thinking about investment and which are highly protected at the moment and, therefore, have to take account of levels of protection-both those which apply at present and those which might apply in the future-in their investment plans. However, if we are to create a dynamic industry economy, we have to look to those sectors of Australian industry which, by and large, are in the low protection category. These are the sectors which are in the international trading environment, which are heaviest into exports, which relate to developments in world trade and so on. These are the long term growth sectors because they are the most naturally competitive. I do not think the picture the honourable senator paints, fortified by some article in the Daily Commercial News, is correct. I concede that a few companies which are operating behind high tariffs might have to take this sort of debate into consideration in their investments, but I do not regard that as a disaster of long term duration.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and relates to the policing of underage drinking here in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). Is the Minister satisfied that amendments made to the ACT Liquor Ordinance in December 1987 have provided a satisfactory basis for the policing of underage drinking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate this question from Senator McMullan as a senator representing citizens here in the ACT. I am advised by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) that the amendments to the ACT Liquor Ordinance of 1975 which were made in December last year have greatly assisted the police in their ability to properly enforce incidents relating to the consumption of alcohol by juveniles. The new laws give police the powers to demand the name, age and address of persons they suspect of being involved in the underage drinking and the right to detain juveniles and issue written cautions without proceeding to arrest. I understand from the Australian Federal Police that early indications are that juveniles are presently heeding the new laws, as the evidence of young persons drinking in public places has declined.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the amendments became effective on 22 December 1987 the AFP has reintroduced a special underage drinking squad. Figures for enforcement action taken by the AFP from 2 December 1987 to 14 April 1988 are as follows: 21 summons applications for offences including stating false name, address or age, and adults sending juveniles to purchase liquor; 14 summons applications for licensed premises selling liquor to persons under the age of 18 years; 178 cautions issued for buying, possessing or consuming liquor, supplying liquor to persons under 18 and for persons under the age of 18 entering licensed premises without a responsible adult; in addition, 21 cautions issued during the Food and Wine Frolic in relation to underage drinking. I believe that those statistics support the general contention of the AFP that the new Liquor Ordinance has proved successful in curbing the displays of underage drinking which were of great concern to the residents of the ACT generally, particularly in the latter part of last year. When one links that innovation with the very productive discussions held between the Australian Federal Police Commissioner, Mr McAulay, and my ministerial colleague Mr Gary Punch only a few days ago, which have led to the further bolstering of police resources available for community policing duties in the ACT, one has reason to believe that very good progress has been made.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: TIME CHARGED LOCAL CALLS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Last Wednesday I received the Minister's answer to a question upon notice which I asked concerning the amount of money spent by Telecom Australia on promoting time charged telephone calls. In his answer, the Minister said that approximately $608,900 was spent on:

QUESTION.PARA: proposed consultation process on the timing of local calls.

He went on to say that the money was expended on `task preparation, research, printing and media coverage'. I ask the Minister: What did he mean when he said he was `seeking community input to its proposed consultation process'? Secondly, was there a consultation process and, if so, with whom? Thirdly, of the $608,900 how much was spent on the said task preparation and what was the nature of it? How much was spent on research and printing and, indeed, what was printed? Finally, how much was spent on media coverage, how was it obtained and where was it spent?

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily acknowledge that that was not one of the more successful community consultation processes of all time, unless one adopts as one's measuring stick the achievement of an early decisive result. It is really quite appropriate that the Australian Safeguards Office submitted its 1986-87 annual report to the Parliament at this time because of the ongoing debate that we have been having about the safeguards in respect of Australian uranium. Especially noteworthy is paragraph 53 under the heading `Assessment of the Effectiveness of Safeguards' on page 11 of the report. It states:
The principal method used at present by the IAEA-
the International Atomic Energy Agency-

for assessing the effectiveness of its safeguards program is to compare inspection activities actually carried out with a set of deterministic criteria. The results of these assessments are presented annually by the Director-General to the Board of Governors in the form of a report which records that criteria were either met, not met or partially met. This reported method does not evaluate the probability that undetected diversion might occur or identify the most probable ways in which attempts at diversion would be made. Such information would be useful in determining needs for improvement of the system and the optimum allocation of resources in the safeguards program.

Here we have the Australian Safeguards Office admitting that there are deficiencies in its safeguards practices. This is exactly what we have seen in the documents leaked from Euratom and released in the European Parliament and now in Australia. A new type of departure from the safeguards regime has been created which has not been foreseen or assessed by the Safeguards Office.

The most recent Euratom documents that we have-no-one has ever disputed their accuracy-show that Euratom wants further to weaken the safeguards conditions of Australia, the United States of America and Canada by furthering a program of what it calls `flag swaps'. This is basically a means by which uranium from, say, South Africa or Namibia can be given an Australian label, an Australian flag, and thus be allowed to be processed or used in countries which would not normally use South African or Namibian uranium. This information is of the most serious nature because it shows that not only does Euratom not function as a nuclear watchdog, but also it is trying actively to get around the safeguards agreements.

Today our Prime Minister, Mr R. J. Hawke, said that these documents were not at all important, that they were mere allegations and that they had no substance. This is not good enough. They do have substance. These are not allegations. They are facts which show that Australian uranium cannot be safeguarded, that Australian uranium can in fact end up anywhere. We have no knowledge of where it will end up. The Government is fond of saying, `Well, we can trace it on paper. It is a matter of equivalency. We know that an equivalent amount of uranium goes to France, for instance, and it comes out of France'. But let us look at France. France has a totally integrated civilian and military nuclear capacity. Our uranium from the Ranger mine is enriched in France. There is no way that this Government can prove that the uranium that is enriched in France does not end up in Mururoa, in French bombs that are tested in our backyard. It is said that an equivalent amount may be transferred on. That is not good enough. If, say, one's grandfather dies and one goes through a funeral procedure and the body is cremated, one wants to know that his ashes are truly in that urn. One would want verification and proof of that. One would not want any doubt that it might be somebody else's ashes.

It is the same with our uranium. We want to know where the physical uranium is going. At the moment there is no way of tracking it. Euratom is actively moving against tracking uranium and our Government does not seem to care where it goes. I say to the Hawke conservative Government that it had better pay attention to where the uranium is going. We do not know where it is going; it could be going into bombs. We have no control over it. The people of Australian demand that uranium be kept in the ground where it can be safeguarded with the utmost certainty.

The annual report of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation reveals, yet again, another great success for the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee. Early on in the career of the Waste Watch Committee, we pointed out the extraordinary rip-off involved in workers compensation payments within the government service and its agencies. We revealed the extraordinary proportions of successful workers compensation claims in some areas. For example, the year before last 60 per cent of employees of the Canberra Fire Brigade had successful workers compensation claims. In some of the defence factories, about 30 per cent of employees had successful workers compensation claims. There was the extraordinary situation that it was 10 times riskier, in terms of workers compensation claims, to work in a defence factory than to be in the Army.

I am glad to say that as a result I believe of the Waste Watch Committee's publicising of this dreadful situation, and also as a result of some pressures from within the Government to improve the system, we have had a dramatic reversal of that trend of an ever-increasing number of workers compensation claims. The number of claims had reached a ludicrous level. I am glad to say that this report reveals that changes in the administration have meant that for the first time in recent years there has been a significant reduction in the rate by which expenditure was growing. It is now down from 27 per cent for the last five years to a rate of about 9 per cent in the latest year. The report says:
. . . the impact of the change in administration brought about by bringing a large proportion of the total claims processing under direct control was the main reason for the reduction.

This reduction meant that, had the old system persisted, claims for this year would have been increased by something like $35m more than was actually the case. I am glad to say that the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee played a major role in saving $35m of taxpayers' money by bringing very strong pressure to bear to change the system. I am told changes had been under consideration for something like five years but had not actually been introduced.

Let us see what has happened under the Hawke Government. There has been a ludicrous blow-out in workers compensation claims. Back in 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser Government, something like 9.5 per cent of Commonwealth employees made successful workers compensation claims. By last year this had increased to 13 per cent. Why on earth should there be this sudden blow-out? Has it become so much more dangerous to work for the Commonwealth? Why has there been this increase from 9.5 to 13 per cent? I suggest it is because of lax governmental control. This blow-out has resulted in an $83m increase in expenditure-a 63 per cent blow-out in workers compensation spending. We notice this year, according to the annual report, a doubling of workers compensation claims disallowed, either totally or partially. A total of 3,824 claims were rejected. I am overjoyed, as I said, that the Waste Watch Committee has been successful in this matter. We are talking about very large amounts of money. The report points out that an examination of Public Service employees who have been receiving compensation shows that 26.6 per cent, or 2,000-odd, of those who won long term compensation cases received more by way of their combined superannuation and compensation payments than they received before retirement. So there are some very large amounts of money going out.

There is also some criticism by the Commissioner about some elements of the changes. However, I do want to say that still all is not well. Excessive levels of workers compensation payments within government authorities remain. For example, 40 per cent of workers at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard made successful workers compensation claims last year. That is intolerable. Of course, that facility is now being sold. Some sections of government still have workers compensation claims at a level of 23 or 24 per cent. For example, the Territories Department had a 10.5 per cent level of workers compensation claims, while the level for the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade was down to 16.8 per cent. There are still some excessive rates, but certainly there has been a dramatic improvement in the Government's workers compensation area. As I say, this is a great record of success for the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee.

The Industries Assistance Commission report on the wheat industry is a long report that has been awaited by the industry for a long time. I am certain that on it will hinge the future of the Australian wheat marketing system. That system, which has been in operation since 1947, is very good and strong and I am sure that it will continue for many years to come.

In the short time available I would like briefly to touch on three areas relating to this long report. The first is the size and importance of the Australian wheat industry. The wheat industry is still a great contributor to Australia's export income. In the years 1972-73 to 1982-83 the industry's contribution averaged 17 per cent of the gross value of rural products or $2.578 billion, which compared very favourably with the contribution of the wool industry of 18 per cent and of the beef industry of 16 per cent. Bearing in mind that the mining industry produces roughly 40 per cent of Australia's income, we see that the wheat industry produced about 8 per cent of Australia's total exports.

I now move to a matter that has been very much in the news of late-levels of assistance to different industries around Australia. I mention briefly the assistance that has been given to the wheat industry over the years. That industry has been regarded for many years as a receiver of a low level of assistance. Assistance has averaged out at 6 per cent. In the period 1973-74 to 1985-86 the figure ranged from minus 9 per cent to plus 11 per cent, giving an average of 6 per cent, which certainly can be regarded as low. Only in 1986-87, with the downturn in world wheat prices, did the Government have to put up the money for the triggering system under which, if the price of wheat falls below the guaranteed minimum price, the Budget allows a certain amount to be made available to the industry. In that year assistance amounted to $220m and the assistance level shot up to 16 per cent. The nominal average assistance level is now back to 6 per cent.

The other point I would like to make concerns the criticism around Australia of the domestic price of wheat. It has been taken for granted by many people who wish to take it that way that the Australian end user of wheat pays a lot more for it than he should be paying, thereby subsidising exports. That is not correct, as this report very firmly points out. The report states:

The legislation and AWB arrangements for domestic wheat pricing were outlined in Section 3.4.2. . . . Wheat used for human consumption is priced according to a formula which averages fob forward export price quotations for the two most recent quarters for comparable wheats, to which is added $16 per tonne margin to cover the additional cost . . .

That margin of $16 a tonne includes a levy of $1.90 per tonne on freight to Tasmania and the rest covers additional expenditure by the Australian Wheat Board. It covers additional fees to the bulk handling authorities to give domestic flour millers the pick of the wheat over overseas buyers; the cost of reserving stocks of grain for up to 13 months; the cost of reserving the best quality wheat at the fixed administered price; and the cost of giving Australian millers credit for an average of 45 days. These costs quite easily account for the $16 per tonne that Australian flour millers and other consumers must pay above the export price. It certainly is not a subsidy. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

The report from the Australian Council for Employment and Training (ACET) deals with a very important area to which the Senate needs to give some attention. I particularly want to address my remarks to an area which comes under `Other Issues' in section 11 of the report. That section states:

The Minister stated in his letter that the issues he had identified in no way represented an exhaustive or prescriptive indication of the areas in which ACET should become involved, particularly in the longer term.

Other matters which ACET and its committees have identified as warranting attention include employment training opportunities for women and the scope for the local delivery of programs and services by organisations other than Commonwealth or State governments, including community organisations, the private sector and local government. These are possibly two of the most important areas which need to be looked at, particularly in the context of the concern we all have for getting particular groups of people into paid employment. Women are very much uppermost in our minds in that area.

My motivation to make these comments came from spending two days last week at a conference in Melbourne organised by the Australian Institute of Family Studies and the Australian Council of Social Services which addressed the issue of child poverty. One of the major conclusions arrived at by that conference was that unless we can get more women into the paid work force, particularly women who are sole parents, we will not be able to solve fully the escalating problem of child poverty. Certainly there is a multi partisan commitment to solving this problem. I suggest that while labour market orientation, structured training programs and so on, have their place, we need to remember that there are special problems for some people, in particular for mature age women who have been out of the paid work force for many years, exercising their parenting role and who in increasing numbers have had the expectation of being in the paid work force thrust upon them through the removal of the class B widow's pension and the reduction in access to the sole parent's benefit. Many of the structured programs that exist are unsatisfactory for these women and such programs are of little value to women who live in remote areas. DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Reynolds) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to various bounty and subsidy acts.
The major proposals contained in the Bill are:
(i) The implementation of the Government's decision announced in the 1987-88 budget to, terminate the Bounty (Agricultural Tractors & Equipment) Act 1985 as from-15 September 1987 and

(ii) The amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986, to effect changes to the book bounty scheme as a result of the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's report on the Pulp, Paper, Paper Products and Printing Industries.

In addition, the Bill makes a number of technical amendments to clarify certain eligibility criteria and administrative features in other bounty and subsidy schemes, as well as repealing certain expired bounty schemes. These amendments are set out in detail in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, which has been circulated.
I shall now briefly outline the two major proposals which are contained in the Bill.
(I) Bounty (Agricultural Tractors and Equipment) Act 1985

When the agricultural tractors and equipment bounty scheme was introduced in mid 1985, the government believed that it would assist the local agricultural tractor industry and strengthen its position in the domestic market and become economically viable in the longer term. However, since that time, production by the major manufacturer in Australia has virtually ceased, and it has become clear that the scheme has not been effective in maintaining an internationally competitive tractor manufacturing industry in Australia.
In the circumstances, and balanced against other budgeting constraints, the government decided in the context of the 1987 budget to terminate the scheme as from budget night last September.

I should like to emphasise that tractors and parts in stock at the time the decision was made are eligible for bounty payment in the usual way, provided applicants can demonstrate the goods satisfy the normal end use preconditions of the legislation.

Finally, I should like to point out that agricultural tractors and equipment are incorporated in the reference on mining, construction and agricultural equipment currently with the Industries Assistance Commission. It is therefore open to people to put forward their views to the commission on what they consider to be the appropriate level of assistance for this industry sector.
(II) Bounty (Books) Act 1986;

This Bill also proposes amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986, which will extend bounty assistance to the book producing industry to 31 December 1993, and implement various related administrative arrangements as a result of the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's (IAC) Report No. 401, dated 25 February 1987 on the Pulp, Paper, Paper Products and Printing Industries.
Bounty has been paid on certain Australian book production since 1969 in order to assist the Australian printing industry to compete with overseas book printers.

This particular industry is assisted by means of a bounty because, although not a signatory, the Government adheres to the spirit of the Florence Agreement which precludes the imposition of tariffs on books containing educational, scientific or cultural material.

In its 1987 report, the IAC concluded that the book producing sector should continue to be assisted by bounty until at least 31 December 1991. It recommended that the bounty of 20 per cent of net selling price be phased to 18 per cent after one year and to 13.5 per cent after two years. Further it was recommended that no changes be made to the bounty criteria which applied from 1 January 1987.

The Government accepted the IAC recommended reduction in book bounty rate to 13.5 per cent, which is equivalent to a 15 per cent tariff. However, as the industry had already suffered rapid bounty reductions over recent years, it was decided to phase in the reductions over four years rather than two years with an extension of the scheme to 31 December 1993, thus producing a more stable assistance environment allowing the industry to confidently make long term plans.
Accordingly the book bounty will remain at 20 per cent until 31 December 1988. Bounty will then be reduced to:
18 per cent from 1 January 1989
16 per cent from 1 January 1990
14 per cent from 1 January 1991
13.5 per cent from 1 January 1992
The Government will again review assistance to the book industry prior to the 31 December 1993 expiry of the existing scheme.

The Government has also decided that although existing administrative procedures should generally continue, certain changes should be made to facilitate more efficient administration of the scheme. In brief, the Government has decided that:
a minimum claim of $500 per title per production run will be introduced for all claims for book bounty, replacing the current $200 minimum claim limit;

bounty will be paid on a production run of 1000 copies or more which includes more than one type of eligible binding of the same book, so that hardback and paperback editions of the one book produced together will be treated as having been printed in the one production run;
packaging used for promotional purposes and sold with a book eligible for bounty will now be bountiable;
all children's books over 16 pages when the text is not less than 3 mm, irrespective of whether or not the book contains pictures, will be bountiable; and
self-financing government publishing enterprises producing and marketing books in substantial competition with the private sector will now be eligible to receive bounty.

With regard to these proposed administrative changes it is considered that raising the minimum claim from the existing $200 per title per production run to $500 will assist administrative efficiency by reducing the number of book bounty claims while not disadvantaging small bounty printer claimants. The national book industry review committee has maintained that claims between $200 and $500 account for less than 5 per cent of these claimants' output, and usually involves specialist work not subject to overseas competition.

The proposed change relating to the binding of books will remove the present provision in the act which prohibits variations to book binding material when the production run of a particular book is assessed for eligibility. This means that the same book printed in both casebound and paperback form cannot be combined in the same production run. Representations from the industry argued that this discriminates against casebound books. Production runs of casebound books are often less than 1000 copies, and therefore ineligible for bounty.

The exclusion of these books because of binding variation represents too fine a distinction and defeats the intention of the book bounty. The government has therefore decided that a production run be defined as including more than one type of eligible binding of the same book. This change is proposed to be made retrospective to 1 January 1987, the date of commencement of the current act.

Similarly, the proposed amendment relating to packaging will remove an impediment under the existing Act which allows packaging for the purpose of transport to be eligible for bounty, but not if the packing is used for promotional purposes. Packaging for an imported book is not dutiable as it forms part of the imported product. The use of packaging for promotional purposes is common in the book industry, and when used in this way for an imported book does not attract duty.

To draw a dichotomy between this packaging and packaging used in advertising a book which is locally produced is therefore inconsistent and discriminates against the local book production industry. For these reasons the Government considers it appropriate that bounty be now paid for packaging used for promotional purposes.
The proposed amendments relating to children's books are intended to remove both an anomaly in the present legislation, and an administrative problem which has arisen.

The Act provides for children's picture books over 16 pages to be eligible for bounty while other children's books are required to have a minimum of 49 pages to become eligible. Children's picture books containing a continuous narrative are also excluded unless the minimum size of the text is not less than 3mm, and the pictures form the principal interest in the book. It is anomalous that children's picture books are eligible for bounty while other children's books are not.

It is considered that administration problems relating to children's story books and adult story books can be resolved by establishing a standard minimum text size for children's books. It is generally accepted within the industry that 3mm is an appropriate minimum size.

By allowing all children's books over 16 pages when the text is no less than 3mm, and children's books over 16 pages with pictures only to be eligible for bounty, it is considered both the anomaly and administration problems will be resolved.
Finally, the proposal to make bountiable certain work produced by a Government instrumentality is intended to address two problems being encountered in the present legislation.

Currently, when an eligible process is sub-contracted to a Government Printer this renders the book ineligible for bounty. The Tasmanian Government Printer has requested that as bindery facilities are only available in Tasmania through the Government Printing Office, private sector printers be permitted to sub-contract bindery work to the Tasmanian Government Printer without forfeiting their eligibility to claim book bounty. In order to solve this difficulty, the Government has decided that when an eligible process is subcontracted to a Government Printer or other authority of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory, this will not render other eligible processes undertaken by the private sector for that book ineligible for bounty.

Bounty will continue to not be payable to the Commonwealth, a State or Territory or an authority of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory for book production. However it has been decided that self financing Government Publishing Enterprises, when they are producing and marketing in substantial competition with the private sector, should not be unduly disadvantaged relative to the private sector.

Accordingly it is proposed by this Bill to give the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce the power to determine exemptions from bounty exclusion for such self financing Government enterprises.
The detail and mechanics of this exemption process, together with the previously mentioned administrative changes, are further discussed in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Financial impact statement

Bounty payments to the book industry under the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 will be $18.4 million during the 1987-88 financial year, and are expected to be $21.4 million during financial year 1988-89 and $19.3 million in financial year 1989-90.
The termination of the Agricultural Tractors Scheme is expected to save $900,000 in the 1987-88 financial year.
The other proposed Amendments in the Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
