SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 is a continuation of Labor's attack by stealth on the superannuation provisions of millions of Australians. It is yet another example of this Hawke Labor Government being completely out of touch with the people of Australia and of its lack of responsibility. The legislation emphasises the arrogance of this Government in governing by Press release rather than through Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: A significant part of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) purports to give legislative effect to statements from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in a Press release of 12 January 1987. It is absolutely outrageous that people have had to wait over 13 months to learn the specific way in which the Government decisions will apply to them. In this respect I refer particularly to superannuation annuities, which are dealt with in this Bill. An annuity may be described as something that allows an investor, usually a retiree, to buy a future stream of income with a current capital sum. Annuities have been used as eligible deposits for roll-over purposes as lump sum superannuation payments made to retirees as a legitimate means of deferring the tax on lump sum superannuation payments.

The most profound change to retirement planning in recent memory was the introduction of lump sum taxation and the closely related move to established roll-over funds. These funds allow the tax free environment that has long been accepted as desirable for the efficient accumulation of meaningful retirement capital to continue undisturbed by individuals changing employment or going into semi-retirement. The initial legislation sought to establish approved deposit funds as the vehicle for this accumulation process, but the Government subsequently recognised deferred annuities as an alternative vehicle. The recognition of deferred annuities and the fact that that had the effect of creating two somewhat different but parallel vehicles meant that some substantive revision was inevitable.

The revision came on 12 January 1987 in yet another example of this Government's legislation by Press release. Now, more than 13 months later, the Government has introduced, and today 15 months later we are debating, the actual amending legislation. For all that time, retirees have had to base their investment decisions on a Press release. The only additional source of advice has been income tax ruling reference 87/1856/3 issued by the Australian Taxation Office. However, that was not issued until 23 December 1987. It is now assumed that the legislation we are debating today, in part, purports to implement and therefore supersede that ruling as well as supersede the January 1987 Press release and also implement and give effect to that statement.

These facts point to a range of matters which emphasise the Government's incompetent handling of this issue which is of such great importance to ageing people. Over the past year thousands of people reaching the age of 65 years have had to make one of the most important decisions of their lives, usually involving the largest amount of money they have ever had to handle, simply on the basis of interpreting a Press release. The Press release left a degree of uncertainty as to the nature of annuity contracts eligible for roll-over concessions. This resulted in a range of interpretations being offered to retirees by investment advisers, generally in good faith but largely in a vacuum as a result of the absence of specific legislation or a Tax Office ruling.

Retirement planning is now more complex than ever before, compounded by the confusion the Government has created over this matter. It is easy to understand the fear and insecurity felt by elderly people in this climate of uncertainty. Can there be any doubt that the Hawke Labor Government is out of touch with the Australian people? Sadly, this fear and insecurity has been shown to be fully justified by both the draft tax ruling and this legislation. A substantial body of informed opinion is of the view that, in relation to the treatment of annuities, this Bill is at variance with the December 1987 tax ruling and is also at variance with the January 1987 Press release.

The Government's whole attitude to people's investments in annuities is frightening. The Government's guidelines, issued on 23 December, are inconsistent with the Press release of 12 January last year and are inconsistent with this legislation. Yet this Bill is intended to be the legislative basis of the Treasurer's statement of 12 January last year. The relevant part of that statement reads:

To be eligible for roll-over purposes, an annuity contract will be required to be such that the payments expected to be made over the anticipated term of the annuity (including any period during which a residuary annuity may be payable) are reasonable-having regard to the expected earnings of the issuer on the purchase price, the expected term of the annuity and any variation on the level of payments over that term-and are not, in aggregate, less than the income expected to be earned by the annuity issuer (and passed on to the annuity purchased) on the amount rolled over at the time of roll-over.

This paragraph concedes two things: first, that the actual mechanics by which annuities operate result in a measure of deferment of the derivation of income; and secondly, that the reasonable deferment was a necessary element to make annuities attractive and consequently help the Government attain its objective of having retirement lump sums, in particular, invested in income producing areas. However, the December 1987 draft income tax ruling examined the legal definition of an annuity and argued that a variable annuity product was not an annuity at law. In this event, the ruling argued, the product was not an eligible annuity and eligible termination payment amounts rolled over into such products would not escape lump sum tax at the time of roll-over.

This Bill sets out criteria with which annuities have to comply in order to be given favourable treatment for income tax purposes. The criteria with which the annuities must now conform, and they are contained in the Bill, go well beyond the Treasurer's statement of 12 January 1987. The Bill also interprets the meaning of the word `annuity'. Specifically, it provides that, unless certain restrictions of payment amounts on commutation and termination, and with respect to deferment of derivation of income, are complied with, the annuity will not be annuity for the purposes of the Act. This interpretation implies retrospectivity. The impact of retrospectivity, if the Bill proceeds, will be to occasion severe hardship to people who have in good faith invested their retirement savings in annuities-something which the Government has gone to some lengths to encourage. As well, the elimination of variable annuities would result in a large portion of retirees forsaking annuities and taking lump sums-again something which this Government has gone to some lengths to discourage.

The reason annuities did not achieve widespread acceptance in the past was that they were too much of an actuarial gamble. The investor, or annuitant, gave his capital to an insurance company in return for an agreed stream of income for life, with the size of that income being determined partly by the insurance company's expectation of how long the annuitant would live. If annuitants lived longer than expected, they won. If they died earlier, the insurance company won-or, more correctly, the short-livers subsidised the long-livers, and the beneficiaries of the short-livers missed out. It has never surprised me that most people preferred alternatives to this situation.

A central factor in the old-style annuity was the giving up by annuitants of all claims to their capital and the returns earned on it in return for a stream of income. The provider of an annuity, usually an insurance institution, has no certain knowledge of what returns will be earned in the future on capital placed in its hands today. If the institution must provide a guaranteed income return, as this legislation appears to require, it will obviously err on the conservative side when projecting the expected income returns on which the annuity payments will be based. The effect of this will be to consign the annuity market to providing a less than full rate of return to people on what is usually the largest single accumulation of capital they ever have to handle-their superannuation lump sum.

The Government has appeared to be concerned that, once annuities are able to offer returns over time that reflect the underlying earnings performance of the pool of investments on which the payments are based, the way is opened up for people to take advantage of the tax concession that exists in the area of annuities. Rather than tackling the issue of putting guidelines in place to ensure that the tax position is satisfactorily controlled, the Australian Taxation Office has issued a draft ruling, which this legislation may confirm, destroying the attractiveness of annuities and returning them to their position in the past when they were largely overlooked by Australians as a source of retirement income.

Can this be what the Treasurer intended in his January 1987 statement? According to that statement, it was intended that the income stream from an annuity be absolutely related to the investment returns earned by the annuity fund manager. One difficulty with the January statement was that it did not specify how the future rate of return could be accurately estimated at the time of entering an annuity contract. But that is far from an insurmountable problem. A variable annuity is designed to provide a facility whereby the investment returns can be accurately reported and annuity withdrawals adjusted from time to time to reflect these earnings. The December ruling and this legislation deem contracts involving such arrangements to be ineligible annuities and such roll-overs to be ineffectual. The December ruling and the legislation deem contracts involving such arrangements to be ineligible. It is not surprising that insurance companies claim that they have legal advice that this statement is not legally supportable.

Further, the legislation casts doubt on annuities which have an investment account maintained by a life office in the purchaser's name. This is clearly a departure from the spirit of the January 1987 statement because it is necessary to have such arrangements if the income stream from an annuity is to reflect the earnings of the annuity fund. So the measures in the Bill go much further than the valid objective of preventing tax avoidance through unreasonable deferral of income.

It is an outrageous infringement of individual liberty for these measures to prohibit greater than the annuity purchase price being paid at termination or commutation. Under these provisions the individual depositor may retain the right of sight of capital only to the extent of the purchase price, and in some cases the reduced purchase price, of an annuity, otherwise the investment will not be accepted as an annuity for tax purposes. By forbidding the investor to retain full sight of capital, this Labor Government is forbidding retirees from obtaining the optimum income stream year by year as well as the optimum capital payout on commutation, termination or death.

To prevent tax avoidance it is reasonable that the investor be prevented from determining the amount of annuity income year by year. However, it is completely unacceptable to prevent investors from having annual variations in income according to the earnings of that investor's capital investment. It is also completely unacceptable that an above average capital appreciation performance by the funds invested should be prevented from benefiting the investor or his or her beneficiaries in the event of termination, commutation or death.

Through this legislation this Labor Government is condemning retirees who invest in annuities to a lower standard of living than ought to be the case for any given superannuation sum rolled over into annuities. Quite simply, if sight of capital is to be denied, an insurance company cannot limit liability to the balance of the amount invested. This will deter annuity funds from being invested in other than fixed interest securities.

Why is the Government so opposed to annuities based on a capital guarantee? It is a proven fact that the best returns for retirees would be obtained from a mixed portfolio of investments, including equities and fixed interest, incorporating a capital guarantee. By banning the retention of sight of capital, this Labor Government is limiting annuity income to that obtainable from fixed interest investments. It is nonsense to talk about security of capital in these circumstances. The capital will be all gone, used up unnecessarily because of this legislation, in supplementing the interest income year by year in an attempt by retirees to eke out a very modest lifestyle. Furthermore, if sight of capital retention is lost, on what basis can a commutation payment be made to beneficiaries in, say, the fifth year of a 10-year term certain annuity contract in the event of the investor's death?

It appears that the rapacious desire of this Labor Government for tax revenue, which reflects its complete inability to discipline its own spending, has overruled its desire to see retirees convert lump sum superannuation into annuities. This legislation is therefore a clear demonstration of the incompetence of this Government and the extent to which it has lost touch with the aspirations of the Australian people. It is throwing out the baby with the bath water. Or is it part of Labor's hidden agenda to deny people the opportunity to accumulate assets on their retirement to pass on to their children?

Part of that hidden agenda as leaked by the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, is an attack on the right to private property. Let me remind the people of Australia about this Labor Government's opposition to private property by quoting the unambiguous statement of the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, a senior Cabinet member and strategist for this Government. In 1986 Minister Blewett said:
We shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy, because privacy, in many ways, is . . . very much associated with the right to private property.

TALK.START.PARA: —True to his word.

—Very true to his word. This is a clear denigration of private property and hence asset accumulation by a senior Minister on behalf of the Government. No wonder the Government seeks to deny people the right through this legislation to maintain a capital asset from their superannuation. No wonder we are now hearing rumours that subsequent to this legislation, which removes the attractiveness of annuities by denying retention of sight of capital and hence the likelihood that people will voluntarily enter such investments, that the Government will remove the right to lump sum superannuation and force people into annuities. It is the only way after this legislation is passed in which people are likely to enter into annuities.

SPEECH.PARA: This would leave people with inadequate income in their retirement but would deny them the right to adequate assets. That is the rule of this Labor Government. So not only have we waited for more than 12 months for some clarification of the uncertainty created by the January 1987 statement, but now that we have it it is inconsistent with the original statement and will cause the Australian people much further worry and uncertainty-uncertainty which has plagued retirees for more than a year, uncertainty as to what constitutes an eligible annuity, uncertainty as to what a surviving spouse or children will be able to recoup from an annuity in the event of death, and uncertainty as to the assessable and non-assessable components of an annuity for pay as you earn tax deduction purposes. The certainty is this Government's hostility to people maintaining assets. The certainty is that this Government wants to get its hands on a bigger slice of people's lifetime savings-revenue at any cost, as long as the cost is not to the Government itself. Through no fault of their own thousands of Australians about to retire or planning for their retirement have been thrown into confusion. Having been given one set of rules to play by, they are now finding out that just before the final siren sounds the rules have been changed and they are not as far in front as they have been led to believe.

Now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is on record as refusing to rule out the possibility of taxing the investment income of superannuation funds or employer contributions in its review of business taxation. But superannuation should not be the subject of discussion on business taxation. Superannuation is the property of the individual. It is the way in which people use their incomes to provide for their future happiness and welfare and the future of their children. Any taxes in this area are direct disincentives to Australians to make provision for retirement. The Government must come clean on options it is considering such as retrospective tax on lump sum payouts, blocking access to lump sums, removing tax deductions from employer contributions, including superannuation as part of fringe benefits tax arrangements, or introducing a levy to fund the basic pension.

On 9 February the Opposition confirmed its total rejection of any proposals resulting in retrospective taxation of superannuation benefits and called on the Government to clarify its position. On 18 February, after repeated questioning by the Opposition, the Prime Minister announced that the Government was not contemplating changes which would damage already accrued benefits but that it would not stop people from taking lump sums and superannuation would continue to be treated on a concessional basis. However, the Prime Minister did not rule out taxing the investment income of superannuation funds nor the possibility that employer contributions would be taxed, nor did he say that the existing tax on lump sums would remain the same.

The coalition policy is constant; Government policy depends on which Press release one believes, and even then there are many holes. For the Government to wait until the May economic statement is made by the Treasurer, subjecting the Australian people to further worry and uncertainty, is irresponsible and uncaring. It is another indication of the arrogance with which this Government operates, which has cost it dearly at the polls and cast such an unnecessary extra burden on the Australian people. How can we hope for social justice from people such as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who believes that anybody who has superannuation or sells it is a tax cheat?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or that Minister asleep over there.

—He has a similar view, I am sure. The fact is that this Government is the greatest tax cheat in the history of Australia. It has cheated by pilfering people's pockets so much that their standard of living has eroded, incentive has been removed from the work force and the population rendered dependent on the goodwill of the state. Now we have a Prime Minister meekly beating his breast, after getting loud and clear electoral messages, explaining that it is not so much Labor's policies and actions that are not wanted by the people, it is just that the poor dears have not understood that the Government knows what is best for them. So the Government has to explain it to them better. Well, I have got news for the Prime Minister. The very great majority of Australians, including traditional Labor supporters, are sick and tired of handouts to trendy and vociferous minorities, pandering to the power brokers, adherence to the old mates Act, and sly pocket picking through more and more inventive forms of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians are prepared to tighten their belts day by day and to live a little more frugally if the Government can be trusted to look after the future and if its long range plans are acceptable. But the public can now see that Labor is not the slightest bit interested in the future well-being of the individual. It is the state which matters to Labor, particularly the state's financial ledgers. The real message from the polls is a clear and simple one. The message from Australians to those politicians who have set themselves apart from mainstream Australia, while they pander left, right and centre about them, is `We do not want the future that you want for us'. Temporary belt tightening and a loss of living standards is one thing. Wrecking their plans for the future is another. How many more indicators are needed before this Government of blind Freddies will accept direction from the people it purports to represent?

Here is the latest message on the subject of superannuation. The following points are taken from a survey conducted in Sydney, Melbourne and the Australian Capital Territory by Arbes and Hall. Fifty-seven per cent of people surveyed said that while some form of old age pension would be maintained in future years, they believed the Government would reduce the level of pension paid. Ninety-one per cent said that taxation incentives should be given for people to prepare for their retirement through a superannuation scheme. Eighty-nine per cent of respondents said that superannuation was not just for the working partner in a marriage but should also be provided for the non-working spouse, and that any new taxes would represent a double tax as both marriage partners are affected. Eighty-seven per cent believe taxes should not be introduced on superannuation fund investment income, and a staggering 92 per cent did not want an increased tax on lump sum superannuation payments.

The survey indicated that if new or increased taxes were introduced, only 34 per cent would keep paying into a superannuation scheme. The majority of the remainder would reduce the amounts they paid into schemes, try to get out of their current schemes, or see whether they could invest more safely elsewhere. Seventy per cent said that this issue would cause them to change their vote. I believe we have seen that reflected in the recent by-elections in Adelaide, Port Adelaide and Groom and in the New South Wales State election.

Two more significant points emerge from this survey. Firstly, political affiliations had little influence on responses. Secondly, 69 per cent of people thought that superannuation was of general value to all income earners and not just to so-called high income fat cats. The survey draws the conclusion from the available facts that politicians, stressing their concern about further taxes on superannuation, are clearly in touch with grassroots sentiments out in the community. Conversely, this Labor Government, which is considering such further imposts on superannuation, is again demonstrating that it is completely out of touch with the Australian people.

In the light of community attitudes and needs, this Government must abandon its plans to impose further taxes on superannuation. In relation to this legislation, the Government must change its current attitude that a variable annuity is not an annuity as regards taxation treatment, and instead define appropriate conditions so that tax is not unduly deferred. I venture to say that this is too much to hope for from a Government that has revealed a totally rapacious desire for revenue. It is too much to hope that this Government will take these wholly reasonable steps, because the Hawke Labor Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history.

That is why I wholeheartedly support the Opposition amendment in regard to this legislation. It highlights the general taxpayers' complete dissatisfaction with the increasing taxation burden imposed by this Government. It is hoped that passage of the Opposition's amendment will encourage the Government to wind back this excessive tax regime. The first points of the amendment relate to the fact that this Government is the highest taxing government in post-war history and that in 1987-88 some 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product will be collected as tax. This is an increase of about five percentage points, in effect, an increase of one-quarter in the last 20 years and most of that increase has occurred during the period of two Labor governments-the Whitlam Labor Government and the Hawke Labor Government. The bulk of this increase over the period has been in personal income tax collections. This is borne out by the fact that personal income tax, as a percentage of average weekly earnings, has increased by 10 per cent over the last 20 years. Again, most of that increase has occurred under Labor governments.

Lower income earners, along with everybody else, suffer from this increase. Middle income earners find that they are the hardest hit of all in terms of personal income tax. Not only are they not able to enjoy the benefits of any significant tax deductions but they find that because of bracket creep they are paying an excessive rate of tax on every extra dollar that they earn. This last point is of national economic significance as it directly affects an individual's incentive and, consequently, the level of efficiency and productivity in the economy. The net result is a lower than optimum level of economic activity. It also has the effect of turning people into possible tax cheats, by encouraging non-disclosure of income. That in turn has a detrimental effect on the economy.

As we see illustrated in this Opposition amendment, this Government is hell-bent on increasing tax revenue collections with an increase of some $5.5 billion in this current 1987-88 financial year. The Government has hindered not only individuals but also businesses with new incentive-sapping taxes such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and additional excises and sales taxes. As my colleague, Senator Michael Baume-whom I welcome to the chamber-has ably put it, Australia's tax burden has increased phenomenally in the last few years, putting the lie to the Government's proposition that it opposes a consumption tax. The problem with this Government's consumption tax is that it is totally inequitable and causes a misallocation of resources. As Senator Baume has said, as long as one prefers ball gowns and other luxury items to basic foods such as orange juice, there is no problem. A low income earner cannot afford expensive ball gowns but might regard orange juice as very vital for his health and his children's health-and also flavoured milk is a benefit to children. A low income earner, as Senator Baume says, has to pay tax on those things but a high income earner who can afford an expensive ball gown for his wife does not pay a cent of tax.

As the last point of the Opposition amendment states, this Government has put us all into a foreign debt straitjacket sucking us into the whirlpool of ever decreasing standards of living. Unless this rapacious desire of government stops, we will never extricate ourselves from this straitjacket which Labor has created for us. That is why I support the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition and I seek leave to have that amendment incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is already in Hansard. Do you wish to include it again?
—Yes, please.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The amendment read as follows-
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and
(e) sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(f) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $86.77 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). It is worth taking the time, in the brief amount of time that is left prior to the adjournment, to talk momentarily about the Australian Labor Party's economic record. It is a rather devastating record when we look at the list that quite clearly states that this Government has achieved the highest interest rates ever, record bankruptcy rates, the highest current account deficit ever, the biggest government spending, the biggest tax take, the biggest drop ever in the Australian dollar, the longest public housing lists, record levels of home loan repayments, real disposable income has been down by 10 per cent, tax per week has been up by between 40 and 60 per cent, the average level of unemployment is up, inflation is twice as high as that of our trading partners and hospital waiting lists are growing longer and longer. That is the Government's economic record. Yet the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is prepared to travel around the country bleating that he is achieving great heights for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Australian economy is now in a worse state than at any other time in the past 50 years. Under this Government Australia now has far less, and many more people are the victims of an unequal society, than was the case five years ago. We now have over 150,000 young Australians unemployed. There are 25,000 young Australians locked out of tertiary institutions. There are 100,000 low income Australians who are condemned to the hospital waiting queues of the nation because of Medicare, which has been an unmitigated disaster. There are 60,000 people living on the verge of homelessness and 40,000 people sleeping in the open or in refuges. After five years of this Labor Government an additional 700,000 Australians have fallen below the poverty line. Single income parents with two children have suffered a $42 a week decline in their living standards. Some record! I think it is absolutely frightful that this Government should pretend that it has been doing a good job.

This legislation, which puts into effect a number of minor changes to our massive corpus of tax laws, does not greatly alter the taxation outlook for Australia. It does, however, remind us of the failure of this Government to tackle the whole tax question with imagination and real leadership. It is all to the good that the legislation includes a measure of financial deregulation to encourage offshore banking. This small benefit, however, must be offset against the practical record of the taxation policies of this Labor Government for both the corporate sector and the private sector. There is not a great deal of value in encouraging offshore banking when at the same time this Government provides a powerful disincentive to business investment through a 49 per cent company tax rate.

It should not be forgotten that the down side of Labor's so-called tax reforms was an increase in the corporate tax level from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. Tax at this level needs to be compared with corporate tax rates overseas. When it is, we see that Australia is faring particularly badly. The spectacular change to a 28 per cent level in New Zealand is only one part of the picture. For some time now company tax levels in the United States and Great Britain have stood at 39 per cent and 35 per cent respectively. Yet our rate is 49 per cent. In Canada this year corporate tax rates will fall to 28 per cent, with a 23 per cent level for manufacturers and a 12 per cent level for small business. I suppose that it is blind hope, but we can only hope that this Government will have the sense to look hard at these developments rather than persist in the attitude that Australia has gone as far as it can on the path of tax reform. New Zealand, as Senator Walsh said last December, has not simply fallen for a supply-side hoax.

The Government would do well to consider whether there may not be a very strong causal connection between the high rate of Australian corporate tax and the fact that private investment constitutes no more than 16 per cent of gross domestic product whereas in 1981-82, under a coalition government, it was 19 per cent of GDP

Taxation reform, however, is not something that can be confined to the corporate sector. It is significant that the Confederation of Australian Industry, in its recent submission to the Treasury regarding corporate tax, makes it clear that personal income tax also needs to be reduced. We have already heard from a number of speakers in this debate about the high levels of personal taxation that Australians are currently suffering. We have also heard from a number of speakers about the high levels of consumption taxes with which this country's residents are being hit.

Let us look, for example, at the fuel tax. In 1983, prior to being elected, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) trotted around this country, saying that Australians could expect cheaper fuel. What rot! It was just like the time he went round the country saying that there would be no capital gains tax. Equal rot! Cheaper fuel, to this Government, means raising its take from 6c per litre in 1983, when it came into government, to the current 21c per litre. That is supposedly decreasing the price of fuel. All Australians know, without being told, what they are paying at the bowser now by comparison with what they were paying in 1983.

Let us look at the tax on Australian wines and ciders, which has gone to 10 per cent. Very low alcohol beers have been subject to a 20 per cent sales tax. The tax on alcoholic wine has gone from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. Previously exempt non-alcoholic beverages are now taxed at 10 per cent. We have taxes on snack foods, iceblocks, ice-creams, flavoured milk, fruit juices and all of those other things that families use. When we say that families have gone backwards we are not just making a snide comment for the purpose of the exercise. It is hard, cold fact that their disposable incomes have been greatly reduced. We go even further down with regard to motor vehicles. Tax on certain motor vehicles has increased from 20 per cent to 30 per cent. There has even been a 20 per cent increase in the tax on salt for swimming pools. Once again, these are all family items. This Government keeps telling us that it has reformed personal income tax and that we are all better off. There are not too many people who would find that they are better off. The fact remains that a single person on average weekly earnings had an average tax rate of 26 per cent as of last August compared with a rate of 23 per cent when this Government came to office. Tax per week has risen from $85 to $132. But still we are being told that we are better off.

For the single income family dependent on average weekly earnings, which, as I have mentioned, is paying all these additional taxes, the average tax rate has risen from 17 1/2 per cent to 22 per cent. The family is now paying $112 per week in tax compared with $65 in 1983 when this Government came to office. In both cases, both for the single income earner and the single income family dependent on average weekly earnings, the marginal rate has risen from 30 per cent to 40 per cent. Since this Government came to office the single person is paying 55 per cent more tax and the single income family 72 per cent more tax.

Over the same time, average home loan repayments, as a percentage of not average but medium family income, have risen from 19 per cent in 1983, under the coalition Government, to nearly 27 per cent as of last year. Subsequent reductions in interest rates, whether sustainable or not, still leave these families with a long, long way to go. I think that it is a very cheap political trick of this Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to keep saying to the people of Australia that they are now better off under this Government than they were previously under a coalition government. It is very much relevant to the taxation policy of this Government that the ratio of household savings to consumption has declined from 15 per cent in 1975 to only 10 per cent currently.

This Bill incorporates another minor adjustment to the capital gains legislation by giving reorganised unit trusts roll-over relief. A notional realisation of capital gains would have been unfair, and the Liberal Party supports this move. However, it is again relevant to this debate to note the fact that, some 20 months after the capital gains legislation was passed and 2 1/2 years after it was announced, the Government is still ironing out the bumps that have caused confusion and unpredictability in the business world. Of course, this Bill does not include any relief for the investors who, in the wake of the stock market crash, find that capital gains realised before the crash of 20 October often cannot be offset against subsequent capital losses. That is absolutely outrageous. There are many people who simply will not be able to afford to pay their tax bills as a result of the crash. But this Government has made absolutely no provision for them whatsoever. While I have to conclude my remarks now and carry on on Monday, I am particularly concerned that this Government is trying to whitewash the situation so that the people of Australia believe that they are better off now than they were five years ago.
